name: Phở Bò (Beef Pho)
description: A classic Vietnamese beef noodle soup with rich broth and tender beef.

instructions.step: Rinse beef bones and beef chuck under cold water.
Char onion and ginger over an open flame until fragrant. Alternatively, broil in the oven until slightly charred.
In a large stockpot, combine beef bones, beef chuck, charred onion, charred ginger, star anise, cinnamon stick, cloves, fennel seeds, salt, and rock sugar.
Fill the pot with enough water to cover the bones and beef. Bring to a boil, then reduce heat and simmer for at least 3 hours, or up to 6 hours, skimming off any scum that rises to the surface.
After simmering, remove the beef chuck and set aside to cool. Strain the broth through a fine-mesh sieve, discarding the solids.
Slice the cooled beef chuck thinly. Season with salt and pepper if desired.
Cook rice noodles according to package directions. Drain and rinse with cold water.
Divide noodles among bowls. Top with sliced beef chuck, green onions, cilantro, and Thai basil.
Ladle hot broth over the noodles and beef. Serve immediately with bean sprouts, lime wedges, sriracha, and hoisin sauce on the side.

name: Bún Bò Huế (Spicy Beef Noodle Soup)
description: A flavorful and spicy Vietnamese noodle soup with beef and pork.

instructions.step: Rinse the beef shank and pork knuckles. Blanch them in boiling water for 5 minutes to remove impurities. Rinse again.

In a large pot, combine the beef shank, pork knuckles, lemongrass (bruised), and ginger (bruised). Add enough water to cover. Bring to a boil, then reduce heat and simmer for at least 2 hours, or until the beef is tender.
While the broth is simmering, prepare the spice paste. In a separate pan, heat the chili oil over medium heat. Add the annatto seeds and cook until the oil turns a deep red color. Discard the seeds.
Add the shrimp paste to the chili oil and cook for 1 minute. Set aside.
Once the beef is tender, remove it from the pot and slice it thinly. Remove the pork knuckles and set aside to cool slightly before slicing.
Strain the broth through a fine-mesh sieve to remove the solids. Return the broth to the pot.
Add the spice paste, fish sauce, sugar, and salt to the broth. Bring to a simmer and adjust seasoning to taste.
Cook the rice noodles according to package directions. Drain and rinse.

To assemble the soup, place a portion of noodles in a bowl. Top with sliced beef, pork knuckles, bean sprouts, mint, banana flower, onion, and green onion. Ladle the hot broth over the noodles and garnish with a wedge of lime.
Serve immediately.

name: Gỏi Cuốn (Fresh Spring Rolls)
description: Light and refreshing Vietnamese spring rolls filled with vermicelli noodles, shrimp, herbs, and vegetables. Perfect as an appetizer or light meal.

instructions.step: Prepare all ingredients: Cook the vermicelli noodles according to package directions. Slice the cooked shrimp and pork belly (if using). Wash and dry all herbs and vegetables.
Soften the rice paper wrappers: Dip each rice paper wrapper in warm water for a few seconds until softened but still pliable.

Assemble the spring rolls: Lay the softened rice paper wrapper on a flat surface. Place a few lettuce leaves, a small amount of vermicelli noodles, shrimp, pork (if using), herbs, bean sprouts, and carrots in the center of the wrapper.
Roll the spring rolls: Fold the sides of the wrapper inwards, then tightly roll from the bottom up, like a burrito.
Serve immediately with Nuoc Cham dipping sauce. Alternatively, wrap each spring roll individually in plastic wrap and refrigerate for up to 24 hours.

name: Bánh Xèo (Vietnamese Pancakes)
description: Crispy and savory Vietnamese crepes filled with shrimp, pork, and bean sprouts.

instructions.step: Combine rice flour, coconut milk, turmeric powder, and salt in a bowl. Whisk until smooth.
Slice pork belly into thin strips. Peel and devein shrimp.
Chop yellow onion and green onion.
Heat a non-stick skillet over medium heat. Add a tablespoon of vegetable oil.
Pour about 1/2 cup of batter into the skillet, swirling to coat the bottom thinly.
Add pork belly, shrimp, and onion to one half of the crepe.
Sprinkle bean sprouts over the filling. Cover and cook for 3-5 minutes, or until the edges are crispy.
Fold the crepe in half and cook for another 1-2 minutes.
Garnish with green onion. Serve immediately with Nuoc Cham dipping sauce.
Repeat with the remaining batter and fillings.

name: Cơm Tấm Sườn Nướng (Broken Rice with Grilled Pork)
description: A classic Vietnamese street food dish featuring broken rice, grilled pork chops, pickled vegetables, and a flavorful fish sauce dressing.

instructions.step: Marinate pork chops: In a bowl, combine sugar, fish sauce, soy sauce, minced garlic, minced shallots, and black pepper. Marinate the pork chops for at least 30 minutes, or preferably overnight.
Prepare broken rice: Rinse the broken rice until the water runs clear. Cook the rice according to package instructions or in a rice cooker.
Grill pork chops: Preheat grill to medium-high heat. Grill the pork chops for 5-7 minutes per side, or until cooked through and slightly charred.
Prepare Nuoc Cham: Prepare or have ready a small dish of Nuoc Cham.
Assemble the dish: Place a serving of broken rice on a plate. Top with a grilled pork chop, pickled carrots and daikon, sliced cucumber, tomato and chopped green onion.
Serve: Serve immediately with Nuoc Cham for dipping.

name: Bún Chả (Grilled Pork with Vermicelli)
description: A classic Vietnamese dish featuring grilled pork patties and vermicelli noodles, served with a flavorful dipping sauce.

instructions.step: In a bowl, combine ground pork, minced shallots, minced garlic, fish sauce, sugar, black pepper, and vegetable oil. Mix well and let it marinate for at least 30 minutes.
Shape the marinated pork mixture into small patties.
Grill the pork patties and pork belly slices over medium heat until cooked through and slightly charred.
Cook the rice vermicelli noodles according to package instructions.
Prepare the Nuoc Cham dipping sauce according to your favorite recipe or purchase pre-made.
To assemble, place vermicelli noodles, lettuce, and fresh herbs in a bowl.
Top with grilled pork patties and pork belly.
Garnish with pickled carrots and daikon.
Serve with Nuoc Cham dipping sauce.

name: Cá Kho Tộ (Caramelized Braised Fish)
description: A classic Vietnamese braised fish dish cooked in a clay pot, resulting in a savory and slightly sweet flavor.

instructions.step: Prepare the fish: Cut the catfish fillets into 2-inch pieces. Marinate with 2 tablespoons fish sauce and 1/2 teaspoon black pepper for at least 15 minutes.
Make the caramel sauce: In a saucepan, heat 2 tablespoons of sugar over medium heat until it melts and turns into a golden brown caramel. Add water carefully and stir until the caramel dissolves.
Prepare aromatics: Mince shallots, garlic, and chili.
Assemble the dish: In a clay pot or heavy-bottomed pot, layer the shallots, garlic, and chili. Arrange the marinated fish on top.
Add the sauce: Pour the caramel sauce over the fish, then add the remaining fish sauce and sugar. Bring to a simmer over medium heat.
Braise the fish: Reduce heat to low, cover, and simmer for 45-60 minutes, or until the fish is tender and the sauce has thickened.
Serve: Garnish with more ground pepper, if desired. Serve hot with steamed rice.

name: Chả Cá Lã Vọng (Turmeric Fish with Dill)
description: A classic Vietnamese dish of turmeric marinated fish, pan-fried and served with rice noodles and fresh herbs.

ingredients.name: White Fish Fillets (cod, haddock, or catfish)

instructions.step: Cut the fish fillets into 1-inch pieces.
In a bowl, combine turmeric powder, galangal, ginger, fish sauce, shrimp paste, and sugar. Mix well.
Marinate the fish pieces in the mixture for at least 30 minutes.
Heat vegetable oil in a skillet over medium-high heat.
Add the marinated fish to the skillet and cook until golden brown and cooked through, about 5-7 minutes per side.
Add fresh dill and green onions to the skillet during the last minute of cooking.
Serve immediately over rice noodles, garnished with crushed peanuts.
Serve with dipping sauce (optional): Nuoc Cham (fish sauce dipping sauce)

name: Bánh Mì Thịt Nướng (Grilled Meat Baguette)
description: A classic Vietnamese street food sandwich with grilled pork, pickled vegetables, and fresh herbs.

instructions.step: Prepare the marinade: Mince lemongrass, garlic, and shallots. In a bowl, combine the minced ingredients with fish sauce, soy sauce, sugar, black pepper, and vegetable oil.
Marinate the pork: Cut the pork shoulder into thin slices. Marinate the pork in the prepared marinade for at least 30 minutes, or preferably overnight.
Grill the pork: Preheat a grill or grill pan over medium-high heat. Grill the pork slices for 2-3 minutes per side, or until cooked through and slightly charred.
Prepare the baguettes: Slice the baguettes lengthwise, but not all the way through.
Assemble the bánh mì: Spread mayonnaise and pâté (if using) on the inside of the baguettes. Fill with grilled pork, pickled carrots and daikon, cilantro, and sliced jalapeño peppers.
Serve immediately and enjoy!

name: Canh Chua Cá (Vietnamese Sour Fish Soup)
description: A flavorful and tangy Vietnamese sour soup featuring fish, vegetables, and a tamarind-based broth.

ingredients.name: Elephant ear stems (Bac Ha) or Taro Stems

instructions.step: Soak tamarind pulp in 1 cup of warm water for 15 minutes. Strain the pulp, reserving the tamarind juice.
Prepare the vegetables: Cut okra into 1-inch pieces, halve or quarter tomatoes, and pineapple into bite-sized pieces. Trim and cut elephant ear stems or taro stems into 1/2 inch pieces.
Mince garlic and shallot.
Heat vegetable oil in a pot over medium heat. Sauté garlic and shallot until fragrant.
Add the strained tamarind juice and 5 cups of water to the pot. Bring to a boil.
Add pineapple and tomatoes to the boiling broth. Simmer for 10 minutes.
Add okra and taro stems. Simmer for another 5 minutes.
Gently add the fish fillets to the soup. Cook until the fish is cooked through, about 3-5 minutes.
Season with fish sauce and sugar. Adjust to taste.
Stir in bean sprouts and fresh herbs (rice paddy herb and sawtooth coriander).
Garnish with chopped chili peppers (optional).
Serve hot with steamed rice.

name: Bánh Cuốn (Steamed Rice Rolls)
description: Delicate steamed rice rolls filled with savory pork and mushrooms, served with flavorful dipping sauce.

instructions.step: Soak the wood ear mushrooms in warm water for 30 minutes until softened. Drain and finely chop.
In a bowl, whisk together rice flour, tapioca starch, water, and vegetable oil until smooth. Let it rest for 30 minutes.

In a separate pan, sauté finely chopped shallots until golden brown. Add ground pork and cook until browned. Add chopped mushrooms, fish sauce, sugar, and pepper. Cook for another 5 minutes. Set aside.
Heat a large, flat pan or crepe maker over medium heat. Lightly grease the surface with oil.
Pour a thin layer of batter onto the hot surface, spreading it evenly to form a thin crepe. Cover and steam for about 1-2 minutes, or until the crepe is cooked and translucent.
Using a spatula, carefully transfer the steamed rice roll onto a plate. Spoon some pork and mushroom filling in the center.
Roll up the rice roll tightly. Repeat the process with the remaining batter and filling.
Serve the bánh cuốn with bean sprouts, sliced Vietnamese ham, fried shallots, and dipping sauce (Nuoc Cham).
Enjoy!

name: Bò Kho (Vietnamese Beef Stew)
description: A rich and flavorful Vietnamese beef stew, perfect for a cozy meal.

instructions.step: Marinate the beef: In a large bowl, combine beef with minced garlic, fish sauce, soy sauce, sugar, five-spice powder, salt, and pepper. Mix well and marinate for at least 30 minutes.
Sear the beef: Heat annatto oil in a large pot or Dutch oven over medium-high heat. Add the marinated beef and sear until browned on all sides. Remove the beef and set aside.
Sauté aromatics: In the same pot, add chopped onion and bruised lemongrass. Sauté until fragrant, about 3-5 minutes.
Add tomato paste and spices: Stir in tomato paste, star anise, and cinnamon stick. Cook for 1 minute more.
Combine ingredients: Return the beef to the pot. Add beef broth and water. Bring to a boil, then reduce heat to low, cover, and simmer for 1.5 to 2 hours, or until the beef is tender.
Add carrots: Add sliced carrots to the pot and continue to simmer for another 30 minutes, or until the carrots are tender.
Adjust seasoning: Taste and adjust seasoning with salt and pepper as needed.
Serve: Serve hot with crusty bread, rice noodles (banh pho), or rice.

name: Gỏi Gà (Vietnamese Chicken Salad)
description: A refreshing and flavorful Vietnamese chicken salad with shredded chicken, cabbage, herbs, and a tangy lime dressing.

instructions.step: Poach chicken breasts in simmering water until cooked through (about 20-25 minutes). Let cool slightly, then shred with two forks.
In a large bowl, combine shredded chicken, green cabbage, red cabbage, carrot, and red onion.
In a small bowl, whisk together fish sauce, lime juice, sugar, garlic, and chili (if using).
Pour the dressing over the chicken and vegetables and toss well to combine.
Add mint and cilantro and toss gently.
Serve immediately, garnished with roasted peanuts.

name: Bánh Da Lợn (Layered Steamed Cake)
description: A delicious and visually appealing Vietnamese steamed cake with alternating layers of mung bean and tapioca starch.

instructions.step: Prepare two batters: one with mung bean and one with pandan.  For the mung bean batter, mix cooked mung bean paste with 1/2 of the tapioca starch, 1/2 of the rice flour, 1/2 of the coconut milk, and 1/2 of the sugar. Add a pinch of salt.
For the pandan batter, mix the remaining tapioca starch, rice flour, coconut milk, and sugar with pandan extract and green food coloring. Add the water for consistency.
Grease a steaming pan.  Steam for 5 minutes, then pour a layer of mung bean batter.  Steam for another 5 minutes.
Pour a layer of pandan batter. Steam for another 5 minutes.
Repeat layering until all batter is used.
Steam for a final 20 minutes, or until the cake is cooked through. A toothpick inserted should come out clean.
Let the cake cool completely before slicing and serving.

name: Xôi Xéo (Sticky Rice with Mung Bean)
description: A classic Vietnamese breakfast or snack of glutinous rice topped with mung bean paste, crispy fried shallots, and a drizzle of liquid fat.

instructions.step: Rinse the glutinous rice several times until the water runs clear. Soak in water for at least 4 hours, or preferably overnight.
Rinse the mung beans. Soak in water for at least 2 hours.

Steam the mung beans for about 20-25 minutes, or until soft and easily mashed. While still hot, mash the mung beans with a fork or potato masher. Mix in turmeric powder, salt and 1 Tablespoon of Sugar. Shape the mashed mung beans into a compact ball.
Drain the glutinous rice and spread it evenly in a steamer. Steam for about 30-40 minutes, or until the rice is cooked through and sticky.
While the rice is steaming, thinly slice the shallots. Heat cooking oil in a pan over medium heat. Fry the shallots until golden brown and crispy. Remove from the oil and drain on paper towels.
Once the rice is cooked, fluff it with a fork. Slice or crumble the mung bean ball over the rice. Top with crispy fried shallots and a drizzle of liquid fat (optional).
Serve warm and enjoy!

name: Nem Rán (Fried Spring Rolls)
description: Crispy and flavorful Vietnamese fried spring rolls, perfect as an appetizer or snack.

ingredients.name: Wood Ear Mushrooms, soaked and finely chopped

instructions.step: In a large bowl, combine ground pork, shrimp, wood ear mushrooms, glass noodles, carrot, onion, egg, fish sauce, sugar, and black pepper. Mix well.
Lay a rice paper wrapper on a flat surface. Dip it quickly in warm water to soften. Be careful not to over-soak.
Place a spoonful of the filling in the center of the rice paper.
Fold the sides of the rice paper over the filling, then roll tightly from the bottom up to create a spring roll.
Repeat until all the filling is used.
Heat vegetable oil in a deep fryer or large pot to 350°F (175°C).
Carefully place the spring rolls in the hot oil, ensuring not to overcrowd the pot.
Fry for 3-4 minutes per side, or until golden brown and crispy.
Remove the spring rolls from the oil and place them on a wire rack to drain excess oil.
Serve hot with your favorite dipping sauce (such as nuoc cham).

name: Bánh Tráng Nướng (Vietnamese Pizza)
description: A popular Vietnamese street food made with grilled rice paper topped with various savory ingredients.

instructions.step: Prepare your ingredients: finely chop the scallions and set everything near your cooking station.
Heat a non-stick pan or griddle over medium heat. Lightly spread butter on the surface.
Place a sheet of rice paper on the heated pan or griddle.
Crack a quail egg (or chicken egg) onto the rice paper and quickly spread it evenly with the back of a spoon or spatula.
Sprinkle the ground pork, dried shrimp, and scallions evenly over the egg-covered rice paper.
Cook for about 2-3 minutes, or until the rice paper is crispy and the toppings are cooked through.
Drizzle with sriracha sauce and mayonnaise.
Fold the rice paper in half or leave it flat. Cut into smaller pieces if desired.
Drizzle with chili oil for extra flavor.
Serve immediately and enjoy!

name: Chè Ba Màu (Three-Color Dessert)
description: A classic Vietnamese sweet dessert with layers of mung bean, pandan jelly, and red beans, topped with coconut milk and crushed ice.

instructions.step: Soak mung beans in water for at least 4 hours or overnight.
Rinse and drain the soaked mung beans. Steam them until soft (about 20-25 minutes).
Mash the steamed mung beans with sugar and a pinch of salt until smooth.
For the pandan jelly: Mix agar-agar powder with water. Bring to a boil, then simmer until the agar-agar is dissolved. Add pandan extract and let it cool slightly before setting in a mold.

For the coconut milk: In a saucepan, combine coconut milk, sugar, and a pinch of salt. Heat gently, stirring until sugar is dissolved. Mix tapioca starch with 100 ml water. Add to coconut milk and cook over medium heat until the coconut milk thickens.
Layer the mung bean paste, pandan jelly (cut into cubes), and red beans in a glass or bowl.
Top with coconut milk and crushed ice. Serve immediately.

name: Bún Riêu (Crab Noodle Soup)
description: A flavorful and tangy Vietnamese noodle soup featuring a rich tomato and crab broth, served with rice vermicelli and various toppings.

instructions.step: Prepare the broth: Sauté shallots and garlic in oil. Add diced tomatoes and cook until softened. Add crab paste, ground pork, and shrimp paste. Cook until fragrant.
Add water and tamarind paste to the pot. Bring to a boil, then reduce heat and simmer for at least 1 hour to develop the flavors.
Strain the broth to remove solids. Return the clear broth to the pot.
Prepare the crab mixture: In a bowl, mix crab meat (reserved from straining), eggs, and a pinch of salt. Steam until cooked through and set aside.
Season the broth with fish sauce and rock sugar to taste. Add the cooked crab mixture and fried tofu to the broth.
Cook rice vermicelli noodles according to package directions. Drain and divide among bowls.
Ladle the hot broth over the noodles. Top with bean sprouts, shredded water spinach, mint, and a squeeze of lime juice.
Serve hot and enjoy!

name: Cá Chiên Giòn (Crispy Fried Fish)
description: A classic Vietnamese dish featuring crispy, golden-brown fried fish, perfect for a quick and flavorful meal.

ingredients.name: Firm White Fish Fillets (such as Tilapia or Cod)

instructions.step: Pat the fish fillets dry with paper towels.
In a bowl, combine the rice flour, cornstarch, salt, pepper, and garlic powder.
Dredge each fish fillet in the flour mixture, ensuring it's fully coated. Shake off any excess.
Heat vegetable oil in a large skillet over medium-high heat. The oil should be hot but not smoking.
Carefully place the fish fillets in the hot oil, ensuring not to overcrowd the pan. Fry for 3-4 minutes per side, or until golden brown and crispy.
Remove the fish fillets from the skillet and place them on a wire rack or paper towels to drain excess oil.
While the fish is frying, prepare the dipping sauce. In a small bowl, combine fish sauce, sugar, water, and red chili (if using). Stir until the sugar is dissolved.
Serve the crispy fried fish hot with lime wedges and the prepared dipping sauce. Enjoy!

name: Gỏi Đu Đủ (Papaya Salad)
description: A refreshing and vibrant Vietnamese green papaya salad, perfect as a light lunch or side dish.

instructions.step: Peel the green papaya and shred it using a grater or mandoline. Shred the carrots as well.
Trim the green beans and cut them into 1-inch pieces. Blanch them in boiling water for 2 minutes, then drain and cool.
Halve the cherry tomatoes.
In a mortar and pestle, pound the garlic and chili into a paste.
Add the fish sauce, lime juice, and sugar to the mortar and pestle. Mix well to dissolve the sugar.
In a large bowl, combine the shredded papaya, carrots, green beans, and cherry tomatoes.
Pour the dressing over the salad and toss to combine.
Garnish with roasted peanuts before serving.
Serve immediately for the best flavor and texture.

name: Bánh Bột Lọc (Clear Shrimp Dumplings)
description: Delicate and chewy tapioca dumplings filled with savory shrimp and pork, a popular Vietnamese street food.

instructions.step: Prepare the Dough: In a large bowl, gradually add boiling water to the tapioca starch, mixing continuously until a sticky dough forms. Knead the dough for 5-7 minutes until smooth and pliable. Cover and let it rest for 15 minutes.
Prepare the Filling: Dice the pork belly into small pieces. Marinate the shrimp and pork with minced shallots, garlic, fish sauce, sugar, and black pepper for at least 15 minutes.
Cook the Filling: Heat vegetable oil in a pan over medium heat. Add the marinated pork and shrimp and cook until they are cooked through and slightly caramelized.

Assemble the Dumplings: Pinch off small pieces of dough (about 1 inch in diameter). Flatten each piece into a thin circle. Place a small amount of filling in the center and fold the dough over to form a half-moon shape. Pinch the edges to seal tightly.

Cook the Dumplings: Bring a pot of water to a boil. Gently drop the dumplings into the boiling water, a few at a time. Cook until the dumplings float to the surface and become translucent (about 3-5 minutes).

Serve: Remove the dumplings with a slotted spoon and transfer them to a bowl of ice water to prevent them from sticking together. Serve the dumplings with your favorite dipping sauce (e.g., nuoc cham). Garnish with chopped green onions.

name: Hủ Tiếu (Southern Vietnamese Noodle Soup)
description: A flavorful and comforting Vietnamese noodle soup, popular in Southern Vietnam. This recipe features a rich broth, tender pork, shrimp, and a variety of fresh herbs and vegetables.

instructions.step: Rinse pork bones thoroughly. Place them in a large pot and cover with cold water. Bring to a boil, then simmer for at least 1 hour, skimming off any scum that rises to the surface. This creates the broth.
Add dried shrimp and dried squid to the broth. Simmer for another 30 minutes.
Season the broth with rock sugar, fish sauce, salt, and MSG (if using). Adjust to taste.
While the broth simmers, prepare the toppings. Cook the hủ tiếu noodles according to package directions. Drain and set aside.
Slice the pork tenderloin thinly and marinate in soy sauce, oyster sauce, cooking oil, and white pepper for 15 minutes.
Boil or steam the shrimp until cooked through. Peel and devein.
For the ground pork topping, stir-fry the ground pork in a pan until cooked through. Season with salt and pepper.
Assemble the soup: In a bowl, place a portion of hủ tiếu noodles. Top with sliced pork, shrimp, ground pork, quail eggs, bean sprouts, Chinese celery, and garlic chives.
Ladle the hot broth over the noodles and toppings.
Garnish with fried shallots. Serve immediately with lime wedges and jalapeño slices (optional) for extra flavor.

name: Bún Thịt Nướng (Grilled Pork Vermicelli)
description: A classic Vietnamese noodle dish with grilled pork, fresh herbs, and a savory dipping sauce.

instructions.step: Prepare the pork marinade: In a bowl, combine minced lemongrass, garlic, shallots, fish sauce, sugar, soy sauce, honey, and black pepper. Mix well.
Cut the pork shoulder into thin slices and marinate in the mixture for at least 30 minutes.
Cook rice vermicelli noodles according to package instructions. Drain and set aside.
Grill the marinated pork over medium heat until cooked through and slightly charred. Alternatively, you can pan-fry the pork in a skillet with a little oil.
Assemble the bowls: Place a portion of rice vermicelli noodles in each bowl. Top with grilled pork, lettuce, mint, cilantro, bean sprouts, and pickled carrots and daikon radish.
Garnish with roasted peanuts and serve with Nuoc Cham dipping sauce.

name: Xôi Gấc (Gac Fruit Sticky Rice)
description: A vibrant and flavorful Vietnamese sticky rice dish made with gac fruit, known for its rich red color and subtle sweetness.

instructions.step: Soak the glutinous rice in water for at least 4 hours, or preferably overnight.
Mix the gac fruit pulp with the rice, ensuring it's evenly distributed.
In a bowl, combine coconut milk, sugar, and salt. Mix well until the sugar is dissolved.
Drain the soaked rice and mix it with the coconut milk mixture. Let it sit for 30 minutes to absorb the flavors.
Lightly grease a steamer with vegetable oil.
Pour the rice mixture into the steamer and steam for about 45-60 minutes, or until the rice is cooked through and sticky. Stir occasionally to ensure even cooking.
Serve hot or warm. Garnish with shredded coconut or mung bean paste (optional).

name: Lẩu Thái (Thai Hot Pot Vietnamese Style)
description: A flavorful and aromatic hot pot combining Thai and Vietnamese influences, perfect for sharing.

instructions.step: Prepare the broth: In a large pot, combine chicken broth, lemongrass, galangal, kaffir lime leaves, and chili peppers. Bring to a boil.
Season the broth: Add fish sauce, lime juice, and sugar to the broth. Adjust to taste.
Prepare the ingredients: Wash and prepare shrimp, squid, fish balls, mushrooms, and noodles.
Set up the hot pot: Place the broth in a hot pot on a portable burner. Bring to a simmer.
Cook and enjoy: Add the ingredients to the hot pot and cook until done. Enjoy with noodles and your favorite dipping sauces.

name: Bánh Tằm Bì (Pulled Pork Rice Cake)
description: A classic Vietnamese street food featuring chewy rice noodles, shredded pork skin, and a sweet and savory coconut milk sauce.

instructions.step: Boil pork shoulder until tender. Shred the pork and set aside.
Boil pork skin until tender. Thinly slice and mix with the shredded pork.
Prepare coconut milk sauce: In a saucepan, combine coconut milk, fish sauce, sugar, and salt. Simmer until slightly thickened.
Fry shallots and garlic until golden brown.

Assemble the dish: Place bánh tằm noodles on a plate, top with the pork and pork skin mixture, pour coconut milk sauce over, and garnish with fried shallots, fried garlic, bean sprouts, mint, and pickled vegetables (optional).

name: Bún Mọc (Pork Meatball Noodles)
description: A flavorful Vietnamese noodle soup with pork meatballs.

instructions.step: Soak the dried mushrooms in hot water for 30 minutes. Drain and finely chop.
In a bowl, combine ground pork, chopped mushrooms, fish sauce, pepper, and minced shallots. Mix well and form into small meatballs.
Bring chicken broth to a boil in a large pot. Gently add the meatballs and cook until they float to the surface and are cooked through.
Season the broth with salt and sugar to taste.
Cook the rice noodles according to package directions. Drain and rinse.
Divide the noodles among bowls. Top with meatballs, bean sprouts, cilantro, and green onions.
Ladle the hot broth over the noodles and meatballs.
Serve immediately with lime wedges.

name: Bánh Khọt (Mini Savory Pancakes)
description: Crispy, savory Vietnamese mini pancakes made with coconut milk and turmeric, typically topped with shrimp, mung beans, and green onions. Served with nuoc cham dipping sauce.

instructions.step: In a bowl, whisk together rice flour, coconut milk, water, turmeric powder, and salt. Let the batter rest for at least 30 minutes.
Prepare the nuoc cham dipping sauce by mixing fish sauce, sugar, lime juice, minced garlic, and chili (if using). Adjust to taste.
Heat a Banh Khot pan (or a small non-stick skillet) over medium heat. Grease each mold generously with oil.
Pour a spoonful of batter into each mold, filling it about 3/4 full.
Add a few cooked mung beans and a couple of shrimp to each pancake.
Cover the pan and cook for 2-3 minutes, or until the edges of the pancakes are golden brown and crispy.
Sprinkle chopped green onions over the pancakes.
Carefully remove the pancakes from the molds and serve immediately with nuoc cham dipping sauce.

name: Chả Giò Rế (Fried Egg Roll Nets)
description: Crispy and delicate Vietnamese fried egg rolls made with a thin rice paper net.

ingredients.name: Wood Ear Mushrooms (soaked in warm water, chopped)

instructions.step: Combine ground pork, shrimp, crab meat, carrots, glass noodles, wood ear mushrooms, egg, shallots, fish sauce, sugar, black pepper, and salt in a large bowl. Mix well until thoroughly combined.
Lay one rice paper net on a flat surface. Place a small amount of the filling (about 2 tablespoons) in the center of the net.
Fold the edges of the rice paper net over the filling, forming a small, rectangular roll. Make sure the roll is tightly sealed.
Repeat steps 2 and 3 until all the filling is used.
Heat vegetable oil in a deep fryer or large pot to 350°F (175°C).
Carefully place the egg rolls into the hot oil, making sure not to overcrowd the fryer.
Fry for 3-4 minutes, or until golden brown and crispy.
Remove the egg rolls from the oil and place them on a wire rack to drain excess oil.
Serve hot with dipping sauce (such as nuoc cham or sweet chili sauce) and fresh herbs (such as mint and cilantro).

name: Bánh Đúc (Savory Rice Cake)
description: A traditional Vietnamese savory rice cake, soft and jiggly, often topped with savory ingredients like ground pork, shrimp, and fried onions.

instructions.step: Prepare the Slaked Lime Water: Let the slaked lime water sit until clear and strain out the excess.
Combine the Rice Flour, Tapioca Starch, Salt, and Water (including the clear slaked lime water) in a pot. Mix well until there are no lumps.

Cook the mixture over medium heat, stirring constantly to prevent burning, until it thickens and becomes translucent (about 30-40 minutes). The mixture is ready when it starts to pull away from the sides of the pot.
While the rice cake is cooking, prepare the topping: Soak the dried shrimp in warm water for 15 minutes, then mince.
Mince the shallots. Sauté the shallots in vegetable oil until fragrant and golden brown. Add the ground pork and dried shrimp and cook until the pork is cooked through.
Season the pork and shrimp mixture with fish sauce and sugar. Cook for another minute, then remove from heat.
Pour the cooked rice cake mixture into a greased dish or individual bowls. Let it cool completely.
To serve, top the rice cake with the pork and shrimp mixture and fried onions.
Serve at room temperature or chilled.

name: Gà Nướng Sả (Lemongrass Grilled Chicken)
description: A flavorful Vietnamese grilled chicken marinated in lemongrass, garlic, and fish sauce.

instructions.step: Roughly chop the lemongrass, garlic, and shallots.
In a food processor or mortar and pestle, blend or pound the lemongrass, garlic, and shallots into a paste.
In a bowl, combine the lemongrass paste with fish sauce, soy sauce, sugar, honey, vegetable oil, black pepper, and red pepper flakes.
Marinate the chicken thighs in the mixture for at least 30 minutes, or preferably overnight in the refrigerator.
Preheat your grill to medium-high heat.
Grill the chicken thighs for 6-8 minutes per side, or until cooked through and the internal temperature reaches 165°F (74°C).
Let the chicken rest for a few minutes before serving. Garnish with chopped cilantro or green onions (optional).
Serve with rice, noodles, or vegetables.

name: Cá Lóc Nướng Trui (Grilled Snakehead Fish)
description: A classic Vietnamese dish where snakehead fish is grilled whole, often covered in mud or straw, resulting in a smoky and flavorful experience.

instructions.step: Prepare the fish: Clean the snakehead fish thoroughly. Score the fish along its sides to allow for better cooking and flavor penetration.
Stuff the fish: Stuff the cavity of the fish with lemongrass, green onion, and ginger. Season the fish inside and out with salt and pepper.

Grill the fish: Traditionally, the fish is grilled whole over an open fire, often covered in mud or straw to retain moisture. You can also grill it on a barbecue grill over medium heat. Grill for about 20-25 minutes per side, or until the fish is cooked through and the skin is crispy.
Prepare the dipping sauce: In a small bowl, combine fish sauce, lime juice, and optionally add some chili for spice.
Serve: Serve the grilled snakehead fish with rice paper, rice noodles, fresh herbs, and the dipping sauce. To eat, wrap pieces of the fish, noodles, and herbs in the rice paper and dip in the sauce.
Enjoy!

name: Chè Trôi Nước (Glutinous Rice Dumplings in Ginger Syrup)
description: A classic Vietnamese sweet soup featuring chewy glutinous rice dumplings filled with mung bean paste, simmered in a fragrant ginger syrup.

instructions.step: Prepare the mung bean filling: Soak mung beans in warm water for at least 4 hours. Steam or boil until soft. Mash or blend with coconut milk, sugar, and salt. Roll into small balls.
Make the glutinous rice dough: Gradually add warm water to the glutinous rice flour, kneading until a smooth, pliable dough forms. Add more water if needed.
Assemble the dumplings: Divide the dough into small portions. Flatten each portion and place a mung bean ball in the center. Seal the dough around the filling, forming a smooth dumpling.
Prepare the ginger syrup: Peel and slice the ginger. Simmer ginger slices in water with rock sugar for at least 20 minutes, or until the syrup is fragrant and slightly thickened.
Cook the dumplings: Gently drop the dumplings into boiling water. Cook until they float to the surface and are cooked through.
Serve: Remove the cooked dumplings from the water and place them in a bowl. Ladle the ginger syrup over the dumplings. Garnish with roasted sesame seeds. Serve warm.

name: Bún Mắm (Fermented Fish Noodle Soup)
description: A rich and flavorful Vietnamese noodle soup with a fermented fish broth base, served with various toppings.

instructions.step: Prepare the broth: Simmer the fermented fish sauce with water, lemongrass, and red onion for about 30 minutes. Strain the broth and discard the solids.
Cook the proteins: Boil the pork belly until cooked through. Slice it thinly. Cook the shrimp and fish separately.  Set aside.
Prepare the vegetables: Cut the eggplant into bite-sized pieces and cook in the broth until softened. Blanch the bean sprouts and water spinach.
Assemble the soup: In a large bowl, place rice noodles. Arrange pork belly, shrimp, fish, and eggplant on top.
Ladle the hot broth over the noodles and toppings.
Garnish with bean sprouts, water spinach, banana blossoms, Thai basil, and chili peppers. Serve hot.

name: Gỏi Cá Mai (Vietnamese Fish Salad)
description: A refreshing and flavorful Vietnamese fish salad featuring fresh cá mai (silver fish), herbs, and a tangy dressing.

instructions.step: Prepare the fish: If using fresh cá mai, clean and quickly marinate in lime juice and a pinch of salt for about 15 minutes. This will 'cook' the fish slightly.
Make the dressing: In a small bowl, whisk together fish sauce, lime juice, sugar, rice vinegar and chili garlic sauce. Adjust to taste.
Combine ingredients: In a large bowl, gently combine the marinated cá mai, shredded green mango, shredded carrots, and fresh herbs.
Add Dressing: Pour the dressing over the salad and toss gently to coat.
Garnish and serve: Sprinkle with fried shallots and crushed roasted peanuts. Serve immediately with rice paper for wrapping, if desired.

name: Bánh Bao (Steamed Pork Buns)
description: Soft and fluffy steamed buns filled with savory pork, mushrooms, and vegetables. A classic Vietnamese comfort food.

instructions.step: Prepare the dough: In a large bowl, combine flour, yeast, sugar, baking powder, and salt. Add warm milk and vegetable oil. Mix until a shaggy dough forms. Knead for 8-10 minutes until smooth and elastic. Cover and let rise for 1 hour, or until doubled in size.

Prepare the filling: Soak dried shiitake and wood ear mushrooms in hot water until softened. Dice mushrooms, onion, and garlic. In a pan, sauté onion and garlic until fragrant. Add ground pork and cook until browned. Add mushrooms, oyster sauce, soy sauce, sugar, pepper, and sesame oil. Stir-fry until well combined. Let cool.

Assemble the buns: Divide the dough into 6 equal portions. Roll each portion into a circle. Place a spoonful of filling in the center, top with a quartered hard-boiled egg. Bring the edges of the dough up and pinch to seal tightly.

Steam the buns: Place the buns on individual squares of parchment paper in a steamer basket. Steam over high heat for 20-25 minutes, or until the buns are cooked through. Make sure to keep the lid slightly open so that they won't collapse.
Serve hot and enjoy!

name: Nem Nướng (Grilled Pork Sausage)
description: Delicious Vietnamese grilled pork sausage, perfect as an appetizer or main course.

instructions.step: In a food processor, combine ground pork, ground pork fat, shallots, and garlic. Process until finely ground.
Transfer the mixture to a bowl. Add fish sauce, sugar, ground black pepper, rice flour, and baking powder. Mix well until everything is combined.
Cover the bowl and refrigerate for at least 2 hours, or preferably overnight.
Preheat grill to medium heat. Lightly grease the grill grates with vegetable oil.
Shape the pork mixture into small sausage patties or balls.
Grill the sausages for about 5-7 minutes per side, or until they are cooked through and nicely browned.
Serve immediately with rice paper, fresh herbs, pickled vegetables, and dipping sauce (Nuoc Cham). Enjoy!

name: Bánh Gối (Vietnamese Empanadas)
description: Crispy and savory Vietnamese fried dumplings filled with seasoned ground pork, wood ear mushrooms, and glass noodles.

instructions.step: Soak wood ear mushrooms and glass noodles in warm water until softened. Drain and chop finely.
Soak dried shrimp in warm water until softened. Drain and chop finely.
In a bowl, combine ground pork, chopped wood ear mushrooms, glass noodles, dried shrimp, finely chopped onion, minced garlic, fish sauce, sugar, and black pepper. Mix well and set aside.
In a large bowl, mix rice flour and tapioca starch. Gradually add warm water, mixing until a dough forms. Knead the dough for about 5-7 minutes until smooth and elastic.
Divide the dough into small balls (about 30g each). Roll each ball into a thin circle (about 4-5 inches in diameter).
Place a spoonful of the pork filling in the center of each dough circle. Fold the dough over the filling to form a half-moon shape. Crimp the edges tightly to seal.
Heat vegetable oil in a deep fryer or large pot to 350°F (175°C).
Fry the Bánh Gối in batches until golden brown and crispy, about 5-7 minutes per batch. Be careful not to overcrowd the fryer.
Remove the Bánh Gối and drain on paper towels.
Serve hot with dipping sauce (Nuoc Cham).
Enjoy!

name: Mực Chiên Giòn (Crispy Fried Squid)
description: Delicious and crispy fried squid, a popular Vietnamese appetizer.

instructions.step: Clean the squid tubes thoroughly and slice them into rings about 1/2 inch thick.
In a bowl, combine rice flour, tapioca starch, baking powder, salt, pepper, and garlic powder.
Dredge the squid rings in the flour mixture, ensuring they are evenly coated.
Heat vegetable oil in a deep fryer or large pot to 350°F (175°C).
Carefully add the squid rings to the hot oil in batches, avoiding overcrowding the pot.
Fry for 2-3 minutes, or until golden brown and crispy.
Remove the fried squid with a slotted spoon and drain on paper towels.
Serve immediately with lime wedges and fish sauce for dipping.

name: Chả Huế (Hue-style Meatloaf)
description: A flavorful Vietnamese meatloaf steamed to perfection, originating from the Hue region.

ingredients.name: Wood Ear Mushrooms, soaked and sliced
Bean Thread Noodles, soaked and chopped

instructions.step: In a large bowl, combine the ground pork, ground beef, diced pork fat, fish sauce, minced shallots, minced garlic, black pepper, and sugar.
Mix well until all ingredients are evenly distributed.
Add the sliced wood ear mushrooms and chopped bean thread noodles to the mixture.
Crack the egg into the mixture and mix again until well combined.
Prepare the banana leaf by cutting it into appropriately sized pieces to wrap the meatloaf.
Place a portion of the meat mixture onto the banana leaf.
Wrap the meat mixture tightly in the banana leaf, forming a cylindrical shape.
Steam the wrapped meatloaf for 45 minutes, or until cooked through.
Remove the meatloaf from the steamer and let it cool slightly.
Unwrap the banana leaf and slice the meatloaf into rounds.
Serve warm as a side dish or part of a larger Vietnamese meal.

name: Bánh Canh Cua (Crab Tapioca Noodle Soup)
description: A rich and flavorful Vietnamese crab tapioca noodle soup, featuring thick tapioca noodles, succulent crab meat, and a savory broth.

instructions.step: Prepare the broth: Simmer pork hock in water for about 45 minutes to create a rich broth. Skim off any impurities.
Prepare the crab mixture: Saute minced shallots and garlic in annatto oil until fragrant. Add shrimp paste and crab meat. Stir-fry until cooked.
Cook the noodles: Cook tapioca noodles according to package directions. Drain and rinse.
Combine: Add crab mixture to the broth. Season with fish sauce, sugar, and black pepper. Bring to a simmer.
Assemble and serve: Place cooked tapioca noodles in bowls. Ladle the broth and crab mixture over the noodles. Garnish with chopped scallions and cilantro.
Enjoy!

name: Gà Xào Sả Ớt (Spicy Lemongrass Chicken Stir-fry)
description: A flavorful and aromatic Vietnamese chicken stir-fry with lemongrass and chili.

instructions.step: Cut chicken into bite-sized pieces. Marinate with 1 tablespoon fish sauce, 1 teaspoon sugar, and a pinch of pepper for 15 minutes.
Mince lemongrass, chili, garlic, and shallots. Combine in a small bowl.
Heat vegetable oil in a wok or large skillet over medium-high heat.
Add the minced lemongrass mixture and stir-fry until fragrant (about 1 minute).
Add the marinated chicken and stir-fry until cooked through (about 5-7 minutes).
Stir in the remaining fish sauce and soy sauce. Cook for another minute.
Garnish with chopped green onions and serve hot with rice.

name: Bún Chả Hà Nội (Hanoi Style Grilled Pork with Vermicelli)
description: A classic Vietnamese dish featuring grilled pork patties and vermicelli noodles served with a flavorful dipping sauce.

instructions.step: Marinate the sliced and ground pork with minced garlic, shallots, black pepper, and a tablespoon of fish sauce for at least 30 minutes.
Shape the ground pork into small patties.
Grill the pork slices and patties over medium heat until cooked through and slightly charred.
Prepare the dipping sauce by mixing fish sauce, rice vinegar, sugar, lime juice, minced garlic, and water to taste. Adjust the proportions to your preference.
Cook the vermicelli noodles according to package directions.
Assemble the dish by placing vermicelli noodles in a bowl, topping with grilled pork, fresh herbs, lettuce, and pickled vegetables.
Serve with the dipping sauce on the side.

name: Xôi Mặn (Savory Sticky Rice)
description: A popular Vietnamese breakfast or snack featuring sticky rice topped with a variety of savory ingredients.

instructions.step: Rinse the glutinous rice several times until the water runs clear. Soak in water for at least 4 hours, or preferably overnight.
Steam the glutinous rice in a steamer for about 30-40 minutes, or until cooked through and sticky. You can also cook it in a rice cooker with slightly less water than usual.
While the rice is steaming, prepare the toppings. Dice the Chinese sausage and cook in a pan until lightly browned.
Soak the dried shrimp in hot water for 15 minutes, then drain and coarsely chop.
Hard-boil the quail eggs, peel them, and cut them in half.
In a pan, heat cooking oil and sauté the dried shrimp for a few minutes. Add soy sauce and sugar, then stir to combine. Remove from heat.
Once the rice is cooked, fluff it with a fork. Mix in a little of the shrimp mixture for added flavor.

To assemble the xôi mặn, place a generous amount of sticky rice on a plate or in a bowl. Top with Chinese sausage, shredded pork, quail eggs, the remaining shrimp mixture, fried shallots and chopped scallions.
Serve warm and enjoy!

name: Lẩu Cá Kèo (Gobies Fish Hot Pot)
description: A flavorful and tangy Vietnamese hot pot featuring small gobies fish, fresh vegetables, and a tamarind-based broth.

instructions.step: Soak tamarind pulp in warm water for 15 minutes, then strain to extract tamarind juice. Discard the pulp.
Clean gobies fish thoroughly and set aside.
Heat vegetable oil in a pot over medium heat. Add minced garlic and shallots, and sauté until fragrant.
Add tomato wedges and pineapple chunks to the pot and cook for a few minutes.
Pour in chicken broth and tamarind juice. Bring to a boil.
Season with fish sauce, sugar, and chili peppers. Adjust seasoning to taste.
Reduce heat and simmer for 15 minutes.
Just before serving, add gobies fish to the hot pot. Cook until the fish is cooked through (about 5-7 minutes).
Serve hot pot with fresh vegetables (bean sprouts, water spinach, okra, bitter herbs) and rice noodles on the side.
Squeeze lime juice into the hot pot before serving for added tanginess.

name: Bánh Pía (Durian Mooncake)
description: A traditional Vietnamese pastry filled with mung bean paste, durian, and salted egg yolk. This recipe provides a simplified home version.

instructions.step: Prepare the dough: In a bowl, combine flour and shortening. Rub together until it resembles breadcrumbs. Add water gradually and knead until a smooth dough forms. Divide into 8 equal portions and set aside covered.
Prepare the oil dough: In another bowl, combine flour and shortening. Mix well. Divide into 8 equal portions.
Assemble the dough: Flatten one portion of the water dough, place a portion of the oil dough in the center, and wrap tightly. Repeat for all portions.
Roll and shape: Roll each dough ball into a long oval. Roll it up tightly like a Swiss roll. Repeat twice for each dough ball.
Prepare the filling: Divide the mung bean paste and durian paste into 8 equal portions. Wrap each salted egg yolk with a portion of the mung bean and durian mixture.
Assemble the mooncakes: Flatten each rolled dough, place a filling in the center, and wrap tightly. Ensure the filling is completely sealed.
Bake: Preheat oven to 350°F (175°C). Place the mooncakes on a baking sheet lined with parchment paper. Brush with egg wash.
Bake for 20-25 minutes, or until golden brown. Brush with egg wash again halfway through baking.

name: Chè Khoai Môn (Taro Sweet Soup)
description: A traditional Vietnamese sweet dessert soup made with taro, coconut milk, and tapioca pearls.

instructions.step: Soak tapioca pearls in cold water for 30 minutes.
In a pot, combine water and pandan leaves. Bring to a boil and simmer for 10 minutes to infuse the water with pandan flavor. Remove pandan leaves.
Add taro cubes to the pandan-infused water and cook until tender, about 20-25 minutes.
Drain the tapioca pearls and add them to the pot with the taro. Cook until the tapioca pearls become translucent, about 5-7 minutes.
Stir in sugar and salt until dissolved.
Pour in coconut milk and simmer for another 5 minutes, stirring occasionally to prevent sticking.
Let the soup cool slightly before serving. Serve warm or chilled.

name: Cá Hấp Hành Gừng (Steamed Fish with Ginger and Scallions)
description: A simple and flavorful Vietnamese steamed fish dish with aromatic ginger and scallions.

ingredients.name: White Fish Fillets (e.g., Snapper, Cod, Tilapia)

instructions.step: Rinse the fish fillets and pat them dry with paper towels.
Slice the ginger thinly. Cut half of the scallions into 2-inch segments and the other half into thin rounds.
Place some ginger slices and scallion segments on a heatproof plate or dish that will fit inside your steamer.
Place the fish fillets on top of the ginger and scallions.
Top the fish with the remaining ginger slices and scallion segments.
In a small bowl, mix together the soy sauce, rice wine or sherry, sesame oil, white pepper, and salt.
Pour the sauce mixture over the fish.
Bring water to a boil in a steamer.

Place the plate with the fish into the steamer, cover, and steam for 15-20 minutes, or until the fish is cooked through and flakes easily with a fork. The cooking time will vary depending on the thickness of the fish fillets.
Carefully remove the plate from the steamer. Garnish with the sliced scallions.
Serve immediately with steamed rice.

name: Bún Bò Xào (Stir-fried Beef Noodles)
description: A quick and flavorful Vietnamese noodle dish with tender beef, fresh herbs, and crunchy vegetables.

instructions.step: Prepare the sauce: In a small bowl, combine fish sauce, rice vinegar, sugar, lime juice, and minced garlic. Mix well.
Marinate the beef: In a separate bowl, marinate the sliced beef with soy sauce and a pinch of black pepper for at least 10 minutes.
Cook the noodles: Cook the rice vermicelli noodles according to package directions. Drain and set aside.
Stir-fry the beef: Heat vegetable oil in a wok or large skillet over high heat. Add the marinated beef and stir-fry until cooked through, about 2-3 minutes. Remove from the skillet and set aside.
Assemble the dish: Divide the cooked noodles among bowls. Top with the stir-fried beef, julienned carrots, cucumber, bean sprouts, and shredded lettuce.
Garnish: Drizzle the prepared sauce over the noodles and beef. Garnish with fresh mint, cilantro, and crushed roasted peanuts.
Serve immediately and enjoy!

name: Bánh Xèo Tôm Nhảy (Vietnamese Pancakes with Prawns)
description: Crispy and savory Vietnamese crepes filled with shrimp, bean sprouts, and herbs.

instructions.step: In a bowl, whisk together rice flour, coconut milk, turmeric powder, and salt until smooth. Let the batter rest for at least 30 minutes.
Prepare the fillings: thinly slice the onion, chop the green onion, and rinse the shrimp and bean sprouts.
Heat a non-stick pan or crepe pan over medium heat. Add 1 tablespoon of oil.
Pour a thin layer of batter into the pan, swirling to coat the entire surface.
Add a few shrimp, bean sprouts, and sliced onion to one half of the crepe.
Cover the pan and cook for 3-5 minutes, or until the crepe is golden brown and crispy on the edges.
Fold the crepe in half and cook for another minute.
Remove the crepe from the pan and repeat with the remaining batter and fillings.
Serve the bánh xèo hot with fresh lettuce, mint, and nuoc cham dipping sauce.

name: Gỏi Ngó Sen (Lotus Stem Salad)
description: A refreshing and tangy Vietnamese salad featuring crunchy lotus stems, shrimp, and pork tossed in a flavorful dressing.

instructions.step: Prepare the lotus stems: Soak in water with a splash of vinegar to prevent discoloration. Drain well.
Cook the shrimp and pork belly: Boil until cooked through. Let cool, then slice the pork belly thinly and peel the shrimp.
Julienne the carrots and cucumber.
Make the dressing: Combine fish sauce, lime juice, sugar, minced garlic, and chopped chili in a small bowl. Adjust to taste.
In a large bowl, combine the lotus stems, shrimp, pork belly, carrots, and cucumber.
Pour the dressing over the salad and toss gently to coat.
Add mint, cilantro, roasted peanuts, and fried shallots. Toss lightly.
Serve immediately and enjoy!

name: Canh Bí Đao (Winter Melon Soup)
description: A light and refreshing Vietnamese soup made with winter melon, ground pork, and herbs.

instructions.step: Soak dried shrimp in warm water for 15 minutes, then roughly chop.
Peel and slice the winter melon into bite-sized pieces.
Mince the shallots and green onions. Chop cilantro.
In a pot, bring water to a boil. Add the dried shrimp and ground pork. Reduce heat and simmer for 10 minutes, skimming off any foam.
Add the winter melon and shallots to the pot. Bring back to a simmer and cook until the melon is tender, about 10-15 minutes.
Season with fish sauce, salt, and pepper. Adjust seasoning to taste.
Garnish with green onions and cilantro before serving.

name: Bún Cá (Fish Noodle Soup)
description: A flavorful Vietnamese noodle soup with crispy fish, fresh herbs, and a tangy broth.

ingredients.name: Firm White Fish Fillets (such as catfish or cod)

instructions.step: Marinate the fish: Cut fish into bite-sized pieces. Marinate with fish sauce, sugar, and turmeric for 15 minutes.
Prepare the broth: Sauté minced shallots and garlic until fragrant. Add diced tomatoes and pineapple chunks. Cook until softened.
Add water and ginger: Pour in water and add sliced ginger. Bring to a boil, then reduce heat and simmer for 20 minutes.
Fry the fish: Heat vegetable oil in a pan and fry the marinated fish until golden brown and crispy. Set aside.
Cook the noodles: Cook rice vermicelli noodles according to package directions. Drain and set aside.
Assemble the soup: Divide noodles into bowls. Top with fried fish, bean sprouts, green onions, and dill.
Ladle the broth over the noodles and fish. Serve immediately with lime wedges.

name: Bánh Hỏi (Fine Rice Vermicelli Mat)
description: A traditional Vietnamese dish made from thin rice vermicelli noodles, often served with grilled meats or seafood and fresh herbs.

ingredients.name: Nuoc Cham Dipping Sauce (Vietnamese Fish Sauce)

instructions.step: Prepare the rice vermicelli according to package instructions.  Usually, this involves steaming or microwaving the banh hoi to heat it through.

While the vermicelli is cooking, prepare the scallion oil. Heat vegetable oil in a small pan over medium heat. Add chopped scallions and cook until fragrant and slightly wilted, about 1-2 minutes. Be careful not to burn the scallions.
Arrange the cooked rice vermicelli on a serving platter in a mat-like presentation.
Drizzle the scallion oil evenly over the vermicelli.
Optional: Top with cooked shrimp and/or grilled pork.
Serve immediately with fresh mint, basil, lettuce leaves, and Nuoc Cham dipping sauce.
To eat, wrap a small portion of banh hoi, herbs, and meat (if using) in a lettuce leaf and dip into the Nuoc Cham.

name: Cá Nướng Muối Ớt (Grilled Fish with Salt and Chili)
description: A flavorful and spicy Vietnamese grilled fish dish.

ingredients.name: Whole Fish (such as Snapper or Tilapia)

instructions.step: Clean and scale the fish thoroughly. Make shallow cuts along the sides of the fish.
In a mortar and pestle or food processor, combine the coarse sea salt, red chilies, garlic, sugar, and black pepper. Grind or blend until a coarse paste forms.
Rub the salt and chili paste generously all over the fish, including inside the cuts.  Ensure the fish is well coated.
Let the fish marinate for at least 15 minutes.
Preheat grill to medium heat. Lightly brush the grill grates with vegetable oil to prevent sticking.
Place the fish on the grill and cook for about 10-12 minutes per side, or until the fish is cooked through and flakes easily with a fork. Adjust cooking time depending on the size of the fish.
Serve immediately with lime wedges and your favorite Vietnamese dipping sauce (nuoc cham).

name: Chè Đậu Đỏ (Red Bean Sweet Soup)
description: A classic Vietnamese sweet soup made with red beans, coconut milk, and sugar. Perfect as a refreshing dessert or snack.

instructions.step: Rinse the red beans thoroughly under cold water.
Soak the red beans in water for at least 4 hours, or preferably overnight.
Drain the soaked red beans and transfer them to a large pot.
Add 1500ml of water to the pot. If using, add the pandan leaves.
Bring the mixture to a boil, then reduce the heat to low and simmer for about 1 hour, or until the beans are soft and tender.
If using tapioca pearls, cook them separately according to package instructions.
Once the beans are cooked, add the sugar and stir until dissolved. Adjust the amount of sugar to your liking.
Simmer for another 5-10 minutes to allow the flavors to meld.
Remove from heat and let cool slightly.
To serve, ladle the red bean soup into bowls. Top with coconut milk and cooked tapioca pearls, if using.
Serve warm or chilled.

name: Gà Hấp Muối (Salt-Steamed Chicken)
description: A simple and flavorful Vietnamese dish of chicken steamed with salt, lemongrass, and ginger.

instructions.step: Wash the chicken thoroughly and pat dry.
Crush the lemongrass stalks and slice the ginger.
Rub the chicken inside and out with salt, black pepper, crushed lemongrass, and sliced ginger.
Place a layer of coarse sea salt on the bottom of a large pot.
Arrange the lemongrass stalks and ginger slices on top of the salt.
Place the chicken on top of the lemongrass and ginger.
Cover the pot tightly and steam over medium heat for 45 minutes, or until the chicken is cooked through.
Let the chicken rest for 10 minutes before carving.
Garnish with chopped green onions and serve with lime wedges.

name: Bánh Phu Thê (Husband and Wife Cake)
description: A traditional Vietnamese sweet pastry made with mung bean paste and coconut, symbolizing the bond between husband and wife.

instructions.step: Soak mung beans in water for at least 4 hours, or overnight. Steam until soft, about 20-25 minutes.
Mash or blend the steamed mung beans into a smooth paste. Mix with sugar and shredded coconut. Cook in a pan over medium heat until it forms a cohesive ball.
Shape the mung bean mixture into small balls, about 1 inch in diameter.
In a large bowl, combine glutinous rice flour, tapioca starch, and sugar. Gradually add coconut milk and pandan extract, mixing until a smooth batter forms.
Lightly grease small molds or ramekins. Pour a thin layer of batter into each mold.
Place a mung bean ball in the center of each mold, then cover with another layer of batter.
Steam the cakes for 20-25 minutes, or until they are translucent and cooked through.
Let the cakes cool slightly before removing them from the molds. Brush with vegetable oil for shine.
Wrap each cake in banana leaves or parchment paper before serving.

name: Bún Thang (Hanoi Chicken Noodle Soup)
description: A flavorful and complex Vietnamese chicken noodle soup originating from Hanoi, featuring a rich broth and a variety of toppings.

instructions.step: Boil the chicken with dried shrimp, dried cuttlefish, rock sugar, and salt to make the broth. Skim off any scum.
Add fish sauce and continue simmering for at least 1 hour to develop the flavor.
Soak dried shiitake mushrooms in warm water until softened. Slice thinly and set aside.
Beat the eggs with a pinch of salt. Cook in a thin layer in a lightly oiled pan. Roll up and slice thinly.
Shred the cooked chicken meat. Slice the Vietnamese ham into thin strips.
Prepare the toppings: chop spring onions, cilantro, and Vietnamese mint.
Cook the rice vermicelli noodles according to package instructions.
To assemble, place the noodles in a bowl. Top with shredded chicken, sliced ham, sliced egg crepe, shiitake mushrooms, spring onions, cilantro, and Vietnamese mint.
Ladle the hot broth over the noodles and toppings.
Serve immediately with lime wedges and fermented shrimp paste on the side.

name: Lẩu Gà Lá Giang (Chicken Hot Pot with La Giang Leaves)
description: A sour and savory Vietnamese chicken hot pot featuring La Giang leaves, known for their citrusy and slightly tangy flavor.

instructions.step: In a large pot or hot pot cooker, combine the chicken broth, lemongrass, ginger, shallots, and garlic.
Bring to a boil, then reduce heat and simmer for 15 minutes to infuse the broth with flavor.
Add the chicken pieces to the broth. Simmer until the chicken is cooked through, about 20-25 minutes.
Season with fish sauce, sugar, salt, and pepper. Adjust to taste.
Add La Giang leaves to the hot pot just before serving. Cook for a few minutes until slightly wilted.
Serve hot with rice noodles, mushrooms, tofu, and chili peppers on the side for dipping. Keep hot pot simmering and add ingredients as you eat.
Enjoy!

name: Bánh Mì Chảo (Pan Bread with Meat)
description: A delicious and hearty Vietnamese breakfast or brunch dish featuring a variety of meats, fried egg, and pate served in a hot pan with crispy bread.

instructions.step: Prepare the ingredients: Slice the sausage and pork roll into bite-sized pieces. Chop the onion and tomato. Slice the cucumber. If you don't have pre-made pickled carrots and daikon, you can quickly pickle some with vinegar, sugar, and salt.
Heat a skillet or cast-iron pan over medium heat with vegetable oil and butter. Add the sliced sausage and pork roll and cook until browned and heated through.
Push the meats to one side of the pan. Crack two eggs into the pan and fry them to your liking (sunny-side up or over-easy are common).
While the eggs are cooking, spread pate on the inside of the baguette.
Add the chopped onion and tomato to the pan to briefly sauté.
Once the eggs are cooked, remove the pan from the heat. Transfer the meat, eggs, and vegetables to the center of the pan.
Serve the Bánh Mì Chảo immediately with the baguette, sliced cucumber, pickled carrots and daikon, soy sauce, Maggi seasoning sauce, and chili sauce for dipping.

name: Bò Nướng Lá Lốt (Grilled Beef in Betel Leaves)
description: A classic Vietnamese dish featuring flavorful grilled beef wrapped in fragrant betel leaves.

instructions.step: Prepare the beef mixture: In a bowl, combine ground beef, minced lemongrass, minced garlic, minced shallots, fish sauce, sugar, and black pepper. Mix well and let it marinate for at least 15 minutes.
Prepare the betel leaves: Wash and pat dry the betel leaves. Carefully stuff a small amount of the beef mixture into each betel leaf.
Grill the beef: Heat a grill or pan over medium heat. Lightly brush with vegetable oil. Grill the betel leaf-wrapped beef until cooked through and slightly charred, about 3-4 minutes per side.
Prepare the dipping sauce (Nuoc Cham): Combine fish sauce, sugar, lime juice, water, and minced chili. Adjust to taste.

Serve: Serve the grilled beef in betel leaves with rice paper wrappers, lettuce leaves, pickled carrots and daikon, and the Nuoc Cham dipping sauce. Wrap the grilled beef with lettuce and pickled vegetables in the rice paper, and dip into the sauce.

name: Canh Rau Đay (Jute Leaf Soup)
description: A simple and refreshing Vietnamese soup made with jute leaves, typically eaten during the summer months.

instructions.step: Wash the jute leaves thoroughly and chop them into small pieces.
Mince the shallot.
Heat vegetable oil in a pot over medium heat. Add the minced shallot and stir-fry until fragrant.
Add the ground pork to the pot and stir-fry until it is cooked through.
Pour water into the pot and bring it to a boil.
Add the chopped jute leaves to the pot and cook for 5-7 minutes, or until the leaves are tender.
Season the soup with fish sauce, salt, and sugar to taste.
Serve hot with steamed rice.

name: Bánh Tét (Cylindrical Sticky Rice Cake)
description: A traditional Vietnamese sticky rice cake, often enjoyed during Tết (Lunar New Year).

instructions.step: Soak the glutinous rice in water for at least 4 hours or overnight.
Soak the mung beans in water for at least 2 hours.
Cut the pork belly into small pieces and marinate with salt, pepper, and fish sauce for at least 30 minutes.
Steam the mung beans until soft, then mash them into a paste.
Shape the mung bean paste into small balls.
Prepare the banana leaves by cleaning and softening them by passing them over a heat source or briefly boiling.
Assemble the Bánh Tét: Spread a layer of rice on a banana leaf, then add a layer of mung bean paste and a piece of pork belly in the center. Top with another layer of mung bean and another of rice.
Wrap the Bánh Tét tightly into a cylindrical shape using the banana leaves. Secure with string.
Place the wrapped Bánh Tét in a large pot and cover with water.
Boil for 3-4 hours, or until the rice is fully cooked and the cake is firm.
Remove the Bánh Tét from the pot and let it cool completely before slicing and serving.

name: Chè Thái (Thai-Style Sweet Soup)
description: A refreshing and colorful Vietnamese dessert with a mix of tropical fruits, jellies, and coconut milk.

instructions.step: Prepare the fruits and jellies by cutting them into bite-sized pieces.
In a saucepan, combine coconut milk and palm sugar. Heat over medium heat, stirring until the sugar is dissolved. Let it cool.
Stir in condensed milk to sweeten the coconut milk mixture to your preference.
In individual serving bowls, layer the jackfruit, longan, lychee, coconut jelly, agar agar jelly, and green jelly strings.
Pour the sweetened coconut milk over the fruit and jelly mixture.
Top with crushed ice and serve immediately.

name: Gỏi Tôm Thịt (Shrimp and Pork Salad)
description: A refreshing and flavorful Vietnamese salad with shrimp, pork, and fresh herbs.

instructions.step: Boil the shrimp until pink and cooked through. Set aside to cool.
Boil the pork belly until cooked through. Let it cool, then slice thinly.
Prepare the dressing by whisking together fish sauce, lime juice, sugar, minced garlic, and chili pepper (if using).
In a large bowl, combine the shrimp, pork slices, carrots, cucumber, mint leaves, and Vietnamese coriander.
Pour the dressing over the salad and toss gently to combine.
Garnish with crushed peanuts and fried shallots.
Serve immediately and enjoy!

name: Cơm Chiên Dương Châu (Yangzhou Fried Rice)
description: A classic Vietnamese fried rice dish with Chinese origins, packed with shrimp, char siu pork, peas, carrots, and eggs.

instructions.step: In a small bowl, whisk eggs with a pinch of salt and pepper.
Heat 1 tablespoon of cooking oil in a wok or large skillet over medium-high heat. Pour in the eggs and cook, scrambling them until lightly set. Remove and set aside.
Heat the remaining 1 tablespoon of cooking oil in the wok. Add the shrimp and cook until pink and opaque, about 2-3 minutes. Remove and set aside.
Add the cooked rice to the wok and break it up with a spatula. Cook, stirring constantly, until the rice is heated through and slightly dry, about 3-4 minutes.
Add the char siu pork, peas and carrots to the wok with the rice. Stir-fry for another 2-3 minutes until heated through.
Return the scrambled eggs and cooked shrimp to the wok. Stir to combine.
Add soy sauce, oyster sauce, and sesame oil to the wok. Stir-fry until everything is well combined and the rice is evenly coated with the sauce.
Stir in the chopped scallions. Taste and adjust seasonings as needed.
Serve immediately, garnished with extra scallions if desired.

name: Mực Nướng Sa Tế (Grilled Squid with Satay Sauce)
description: Grilled squid marinated in a flavorful satay sauce, a popular Vietnamese street food.

instructions.step: Clean the squid thoroughly, removing the ink sac and any inedible parts.
Score the squid lightly in a crosshatch pattern to help the marinade penetrate.
Mince garlic and shallots. Mix with satay sauce, fish sauce, sugar, vegetable oil, and chili flakes.
Marinate the squid in the satay mixture for at least 30 minutes.
Preheat grill to medium-high heat.
Grill the squid for 3-5 minutes per side, or until cooked through and slightly charred.
Serve immediately with your favorite Vietnamese dipping sauce and fresh herbs.

name: Lẩu Dê (Goat Hot Pot)
description: A flavorful and hearty Vietnamese goat hot pot, perfect for a gathering.

instructions.step: In a large pot, combine goat bones, water, lemongrass, ginger, star anise, cinnamon stick, red dates, sugar, and salt. Bring to a boil, then reduce heat and simmer for 1 hour to make a rich broth.
While the broth is simmering, prepare the goat meat. Marinate the cubed goat meat with a little salt, pepper, and minced ginger for at least 30 minutes.
After the broth has simmered for an hour, remove the bones and spices.
Add taro root and dried tofu to the broth and simmer for another 20 minutes until the taro is tender.
Season the broth with fish sauce and MSG to taste.
Set up a portable stove or hot plate on the table and place the pot of broth on it.
Arrange goat meat, bean curd skin, enoki mushrooms, Chinese cabbage, and rice noodles on plates for everyone to add to the hot pot.
Cook the goat meat and other ingredients in the hot pot as desired.
Serve with fermented bean curd dipping sauce. Enjoy!

name: Bún Ốc (Snail Noodle Soup)
description: A traditional Vietnamese noodle soup with snails in a flavorful tomato-based broth.

instructions.step: Prepare the snails: Clean snails thoroughly, removing any impurities. Boil them until cooked through. Pick the snail meat out of the shells.
Prepare the broth: Boil pork bones to make a rich broth. Skim off any foam or impurities.
Sauté aromatics: Sauté chopped shallots and garlic in annatto oil until fragrant. Add diced tomatoes and cook until softened.
Combine ingredients: Add the sautéed tomatoes and aromatics to the pork bone broth. Add dried shrimp, turmeric powder, shrimp paste, sugar, salt, and fish sauce.
Add snails: Add the cooked snail meat and fermented rice vinegar (bỗng) to the broth. Simmer for 30 minutes to allow the flavors to meld.

Assemble the soup: Cook the bún (rice vermicelli) according to package directions. Place the noodles in a bowl, ladle the snail soup over them, and garnish with chopped green onions, perilla leaves, and mint. Serve with chili paste on the side.
Enjoy!

name: Chè Hạt Sen (Lotus Seed Sweet Soup)
description: A traditional Vietnamese sweet soup made with lotus seeds, sugar, and sometimes other ingredients like dried longan or pandan leaves.

instructions.step: Rinse the dried lotus seeds thoroughly.
If using dried lotus seeds with the green embryo (bitter core), remove the embryo with a toothpick.
Soak the lotus seeds in warm water for at least 2 hours, or preferably overnight.
If using dried longan, rinse them well.
Place the soaked lotus seeds in a pot with water. If using pandan leaves, tie them into a knot and add them to the pot.
Bring the water to a boil, then reduce heat and simmer for about 45-60 minutes, or until the lotus seeds are soft and tender.
Add the sugar and dried longan (if using) to the pot. Stir until the sugar is dissolved.
Continue to simmer for another 10-15 minutes to allow the flavors to meld.
Remove the pandan leaves before serving (if used).
Serve warm or chilled. Garnish with a few extra lotus seeds and dried longan.

name: Bánh Căn (Mini Rice Pancakes)
description: Crispy, savory mini rice pancakes from Vietnam, served with flavorful dipping sauce.

instructions.step: Combine rice flour, cooked rice, tapioca starch, coconut milk, water, oil and salt in a bowl. Mix well and let it rest for at least 30 minutes.
Prepare the dipping sauce by mixing fish sauce, lime juice, sugar, minced chili, and minced garlic in a small bowl.
Dice the ground pork and shrimp into small pieces. Finely chop the green onion.
Heat a specialized Banh Can pan (or a small skillet) over medium heat. Grease the pan with oil.
Pour a small amount of batter into each mold or area on the pan.
Add a small amount of ground pork, shrimp, and green onion on top of each pancake.
Cover and cook until the edges are crispy and the bottom is golden brown, about 3-5 minutes.
Remove the Banh Can from the pan and serve hot with the dipping sauce.

name: Cá Kho Tộ Dừa (Caramel Fish in Coconut Pot)
description: A classic Vietnamese dish of fish braised in a rich, savory-sweet caramel sauce with coconut water. Traditionally cooked in a clay pot for added flavor.

instructions.step: Prepare the caramel sauce: In a pot, heat sugar over medium heat until melted and amber in color. Be careful not to burn it.
Add water to the caramel slowly to dilute, then add fish sauce, soy sauce and stir.

Marinate the fish: In a bowl, combine the fish fillets with minced garlic, chopped shallots, sliced chilies, ground black pepper, and a tablespoon of the caramel sauce. Marinate for at least 30 minutes.
Cook the fish: Heat vegetable oil in a clay pot or heavy-bottomed pot. Add the marinated fish in a single layer.
Pour in the remaining caramel sauce and coconut water. Bring to a simmer over medium heat.
Reduce heat to low, cover, and simmer for 45-60 minutes, or until the sauce has thickened and the fish is tender. Baste the fish with the sauce occasionally.
Garnish with chopped green onions and serve hot with steamed rice.

name: Gà Quay (Vietnamese Roast Chicken)
description: A flavorful and crispy Vietnamese roast chicken, marinated in a blend of aromatic spices and sauces.

instructions.step: Rinse the chicken inside and out and pat dry with paper towels.
In a mortar and pestle or food processor, grind garlic and shallots into a paste.
In a large bowl, combine the garlic-shallot paste, five-spice powder, soy sauce, hoisin sauce, honey, rice wine vinegar, sesame oil, salt, and pepper. Mix well to create the marinade.
Rub the marinade all over the chicken, making sure to get under the skin and inside the cavity.
Cover the chicken and refrigerate for at least 4 hours, or preferably overnight, to allow the flavors to meld.
Preheat oven to 375°F (190°C).
Place the chicken on a roasting rack in a roasting pan.
Roast for 1 hour, or until the internal temperature reaches 165°F (74°C).
Baste the chicken with the pan juices every 20 minutes during the roasting process to keep it moist and ensure even browning.
If the skin starts to brown too quickly, cover the chicken loosely with foil.
Once cooked, let the chicken rest for 10-15 minutes before carving and serving.

name: Bánh Mì Chả Cá (Fish Cake Sandwich)
description: A delicious and savory Vietnamese sandwich featuring crispy fried fish cakes, pickled vegetables, cilantro, and a flavorful sauce, all stuffed into a crusty baguette.

instructions.step: Prepare the pickled vegetables: In a bowl, combine carrots, daikon radish, rice vinegar, sugar, and salt. Mix well and let it sit for at least 15 minutes.
Fry the fish cakes: Heat oil in a pan over medium heat. Fry the fish cakes until golden brown and crispy. Remove and drain on paper towels.
Prepare the sauce: In a small bowl, mix together mayonnaise, sriracha, and soy sauce.
Assemble the sandwich: Cut the baguette in half lengthwise. Spread the sauce on both sides of the bread.
Fill the sandwich: Layer the fish cakes, pickled vegetables, cilantro, and cucumber slices inside the baguette.
Serve immediately and enjoy!

name: Canh Cua Rau Đay (Crab Soup with Jute Leaf)
description: A refreshing and nutritious Vietnamese soup made with crab meat, jute leaves, and luffa.

instructions.step: Prepare the crab meat: Gently separate the crab meat from the shells, being careful to remove any cartilage. Set aside.
Prepare the vegetables: Wash the jute leaves thoroughly. Cut the luffa into bite-sized pieces. Mince the shallots and garlic.
Make the crab stock: In a pot, combine the crab shells with water. Bring to a boil, then reduce heat and simmer for 15 minutes to make a flavorful stock. Strain the stock, discarding the shells.
Sauté the aromatics: In the same pot, heat vegetable oil over medium heat. Add minced shallots and garlic, and sauté until fragrant.
Add the crab meat: Gently add the crab meat to the pot and stir-fry lightly until slightly cooked.
Add the jute leaves and luffa: Add the jute leaves and luffa to the pot and stir gently until the leaves wilt slightly.
Pour in the crab stock: Pour the strained crab stock into the pot. Bring to a simmer.
Season the soup: Season the soup with fish sauce, salt, and pepper. Adjust the seasoning to your liking.
Cook the soup: Simmer the soup for another 10 minutes, or until the luffa is tender and the flavors have melded.
Serve: Ladle the soup into bowls and serve hot. Enjoy with steamed rice.

name: Chè Đậu Xanh (Mung Bean Sweet Soup)
description: A classic Vietnamese sweet soup made with mung beans, coconut milk, and tapioca pearls.

instructions.step: Rinse the mung beans thoroughly under cold water.
Soak the mung beans in water for at least 2 hours, or preferably overnight.
Drain the soaked mung beans.
In a pot, combine the mung beans with 1500ml of water. Bring to a boil, then reduce heat and simmer for 30-40 minutes, or until the beans are soft and tender.
Add the sugar and salt to the pot and stir until dissolved.
If using tapioca pearls, cook them separately according to package instructions. Drain and rinse with cold water.
Gently stir in the cooked tapioca pearls and vanilla extract into the mung bean soup.
Let the soup cool slightly.
Ladle the soup into serving bowls and top with coconut milk.
Serve warm or chilled.

name: Bún Chả Cá (Fish Cake Vermicelli)
description: A flavorful Vietnamese noodle soup with crispy fish cakes, fresh herbs, and a tangy broth.

ingredients.name: Fish fillets (firm white fish, such as cod or haddock)

instructions.step: Prepare the fish cakes: Blend the fish fillets, dill, green onions, fish sauce, turmeric, and pepper in a food processor until smooth. Shape into small patties.
Fry the fish cakes: Heat vegetable oil in a pan over medium heat. Fry the fish cakes until golden brown and cooked through. Set aside.
Prepare the broth: Sauté minced shallots and garlic in a pot until fragrant. Add diced tomatoes and pineapple chunks and cook for a few minutes.
Add broth and simmer: Pour in the chicken or fish broth. Add sugar and fish sauce to taste. Simmer for 15 minutes to develop the flavors.
Cook the noodles: Cook the rice vermicelli noodles according to package directions. Drain and rinse.
Assemble the dish: Divide the noodles among bowls. Top with the fried fish cakes, bean sprouts, mint leaves, and perilla leaves.
Pour the broth: Ladle the hot broth over the noodles and fish cakes. Squeeze lime juice over each bowl.
Serve immediately and enjoy!

name: Lẩu Hải Sản (Seafood Hot Pot)
description: A flavorful and customizable Vietnamese hot pot with a variety of seafood and vegetables.

instructions.step: Prepare the broth: Combine seafood broth in a large pot or hot pot. Add sliced lemongrass and ginger.
Prepare the ingredients: Wash and prepare all the seafood, vegetables, and mushrooms. Arrange them on platters for easy access.
Set up the hot pot: Place the pot on a portable burner or induction cooktop in the center of the table.
Bring the broth to a boil: Once the broth is boiling, start adding the seafood, vegetables, and mushrooms according to your preference.
Cook the ingredients: Cook the ingredients until they are cooked through. Shrimp and squid will cook quickly, while fish and mussels may take a bit longer.
Cook noodles: Add noodles as desired.
Make a dipping sauce: Combine fish sauce, lime juice, and chopped red chilies to taste for a flavorful dipping sauce.
