Enjoy: Dip the cooked seafood and vegetables into the dipping sauce and enjoy with rice noodles.

name: Bánh Ít (Sticky Rice Dumpling)
description: Savory sticky rice dumplings filled with a flavorful mixture of pork and shrimp, wrapped in banana leaves.

instructions.step: Prepare the Dough: In a large bowl, mix glutinous rice flour with water to form a smooth dough. Knead for about 5 minutes. Cover and let rest for 30 minutes.

Prepare the Filling: Soak the mung beans for at least 2 hours. Steam or boil until soft. Mash into a smooth paste. Sauté chopped shallots and garlic in vegetable oil until fragrant. Add ground pork and shrimp, cook until browned. Season with fish sauce, sugar, and pepper. Mix the cooked pork and shrimp mixture with the mung bean paste.

Shape the Dumplings: Divide the dough into 12 equal portions. Flatten each portion into a small disc. Place a tablespoon of the filling in the center of each disc. Bring the edges of the dough together to enclose the filling, forming a round or conical shape.
Wrap in Banana Leaves: Cut the banana leaves into squares large enough to wrap each dumpling. Fold the banana leaf around each dumpling, securing it with string or toothpicks.
Steam the Dumplings: Steam the wrapped dumplings for 30-45 minutes, or until the dough is cooked through and translucent. Make sure there's enough water in the steamer.
Serve: Let the dumplings cool slightly before unwrapping and serving. Best served warm.

name: Gỏi Măng Khô (Dried Bamboo Shoot Salad)
description: A refreshing and flavorful Vietnamese salad made with dried bamboo shoots, shrimp, pork, and fresh herbs in a tangy dressing.

instructions.step: Soak dried bamboo shoots in water for at least 4 hours, or preferably overnight, changing the water several times.
Boil the bamboo shoots until tender, about 30-45 minutes. Drain and rinse with cold water. Shred into thin strips.
Boil pork belly until cooked through, about 20 minutes. Let cool slightly, then slice thinly.
Boil shrimp until pink and cooked through, about 3-5 minutes. Peel and devein.
Julienne carrot and cucumber.
In a small bowl, whisk together fish sauce, lime juice, sugar, minced garlic, and minced chili to create the dressing.
In a large bowl, combine the shredded bamboo shoots, sliced pork belly, shrimp, carrot, and cucumber.
Pour the dressing over the salad and toss well to coat.
Garnish with chopped roasted peanuts, fresh mint, and fresh basil.
Serve immediately or chilled.

name: Cá Chiên Sả Ớt (Fried Fish with Lemongrass and Chili)
description: Crispy fried fish infused with aromatic lemongrass and spicy chili, a classic Vietnamese dish.

ingredients.name: Firm white fish fillets (e.g., cod, snapper)

instructions.step: Prepare the fish: Pat the fish fillets dry and lightly coat with rice flour.
Prepare the lemongrass chili mixture: Mince lemongrass, chili, garlic, and shallots very finely.
Season the fish: In a bowl, mix the minced lemongrass chili mixture with fish sauce, sugar, and black pepper. Rub the mixture all over the fish fillets.
Heat the oil: Heat vegetable oil in a large skillet or wok over medium-high heat.
Fry the fish: Carefully place the fish fillets in the hot oil, ensuring not to overcrowd the pan. Fry for 3-4 minutes per side, or until golden brown and crispy.
Remove and drain: Remove the fried fish from the skillet and place on a wire rack or paper towels to drain excess oil.
Serve: Serve immediately with steamed rice and your favorite Vietnamese side dishes.

name: Chả Ram Tôm Đất (Earth Shrimp Spring Rolls)
description: Crispy and flavorful Vietnamese spring rolls filled with tiny earth shrimp.

instructions.step: Soak wood ear mushrooms in warm water until softened. Chop finely.
Soak vermicelli noodles in warm water until softened. Cut into short lengths.
Peel and mince shallots and garlic.
In a bowl, combine earth shrimp, ground pork, vermicelli noodles, wood ear mushrooms, shallots, garlic, fish sauce, sugar, and black pepper. Mix well.
Lay a sheet of rice paper on a flat surface. Wet lightly with water.
Place a spoonful of filling on the rice paper. Fold in the sides and roll tightly to form a spring roll.
Repeat with remaining filling and rice paper.
Heat cooking oil in a deep fryer or large pan to 350°F (175°C).
Fry the spring rolls in batches until golden brown and crispy, about 3-5 minutes per batch.
Remove from oil and drain on paper towels.
Serve hot with dipping sauce (Nuoc Cham) and fresh herbs.

name: Bún Thịt Nướng Cà Phê (Coffee-Flavored Grilled Pork Vermicelli)
description: A Vietnamese vermicelli noodle bowl with grilled pork marinated in a unique coffee-infused sauce.

instructions.step: In a bowl, combine coffee, fish sauce, soy sauce, brown sugar, garlic, shallots, lemongrass, black pepper, and vegetable oil. Mix well.
Add the sliced pork to the marinade and toss to coat. Cover and refrigerate for at least 1 hour, or up to overnight.
Cook vermicelli noodles according to package directions. Drain and rinse with cold water.
Preheat grill to medium-high heat. Grill pork for 3-4 minutes per side, or until cooked through and slightly caramelized.
Assemble the noodle bowls: place vermicelli noodles in a bowl, top with lettuce, cucumber, pickled carrots and daikon, bean sprouts, mint, and cilantro.
Arrange grilled pork on top of the vegetables and noodles. Garnish with crushed roasted peanuts.
Serve immediately with Nuoc Cham dipping sauce.

name: Bánh Khoái (Hue-Style Crispy Pancakes)
description: Crispy and savory Vietnamese pancakes from Hue, filled with shrimp, pork, and bean sprouts. Served with a flavorful dipping sauce.

instructions.step: In a bowl, mix rice flour, cornstarch, turmeric powder, coconut milk, water, and salt. Let it rest for at least 30 minutes.
Prepare the filling: Cook ground pork and shrimp separately until cooked through. Chop green onions.
Make the dipping sauce: Combine fish sauce, sugar, lime juice, minced garlic, and chopped chili.
Heat vegetable oil in a small skillet over medium heat.
Pour a thin layer of batter into the skillet. Add ground pork, shrimp, and bean sprouts.
Cover the skillet and cook until the edges are crispy and the bottom is golden brown (about 5-7 minutes).
Sprinkle with chopped green onions.
Fold the pancake in half and serve immediately with the dipping sauce.

name: Gà Nướng Mật Ong (Honey Grilled Chicken)
description: A flavorful Vietnamese honey-glazed grilled chicken, perfect for a weeknight dinner or a weekend barbecue.

instructions.step: In a bowl, mince garlic and shallots.
Add honey, soy sauce, fish sauce, black pepper, sesame oil, and lime juice to the bowl. Mix well to combine.
Place chicken thighs in a large ziplock bag or container. Pour the marinade over the chicken, ensuring all pieces are coated.
Marinate in the refrigerator for at least 30 minutes, or up to overnight.
Preheat grill to medium-high heat.
Remove chicken from marinade and grill for 5-7 minutes per side, or until cooked through and the juices run clear.
Baste with remaining marinade during the last few minutes of grilling for extra flavor.
Let rest for a few minutes before serving. Garnish with sliced green onions or cilantro, if desired.
Serve with rice, noodles, or a fresh salad.

name: Canh Mướp Đắng (Bitter Melon Soup)
description: A refreshing and slightly bitter Vietnamese soup with bitter melon and ground pork.

instructions.step: Soak wood ear mushrooms and glass noodles in warm water until softened. Chop finely.
Cut bitter melon in half lengthwise, remove seeds and pith. Slice thinly and blanch in boiling water for 2-3 minutes to reduce bitterness. Drain and set aside.
In a bowl, combine ground pork, chopped wood ear mushrooms, chopped glass noodles, chopped scallions, fish sauce, salt, and pepper. Mix well.
Stuff the bitter melon slices with the pork mixture.
Bring chicken broth to a boil in a pot. Gently add the stuffed bitter melon slices.
Reduce heat and simmer for 20-25 minutes, or until the bitter melon is tender and the pork is cooked through.
Garnish with chopped scallions before serving.

name: Bún Măng Vịt (Duck and Bamboo Shoot Noodles)
description: A flavorful Vietnamese noodle soup featuring tender duck and crunchy bamboo shoots.

instructions.step: Soak dried bamboo shoots and shiitake mushrooms in warm water for at least 4 hours, or preferably overnight.  Change the water several times.
Rinse the duck thoroughly and rub it with salt and ginger. Boil the duck in a large pot of water with ginger and shallots for about 1.5 hours or until cooked through. Remove the duck and let it cool.
While the duck is cooling, slice the bamboo shoots thinly. Boil the sliced bamboo shoots in fresh water for 15 minutes to remove any bitterness. Drain and rinse.
Debone the duck and slice the meat into bite-sized pieces. Reserve the duck carcass.
Strain the duck broth through a fine-mesh sieve. Add the duck carcass back to the broth and simmer for another 30 minutes to extract more flavor. Remove the carcass.
Add the boiled bamboo shoots and shiitake mushrooms to the duck broth. Season with fish sauce, salt, and sugar. Simmer for 30 minutes.
Prepare the rice noodles according to package instructions.
To serve, place a portion of rice noodles in a bowl. Top with duck slices, bamboo shoots, mushrooms, scallions, and cilantro. Pour the hot broth over the noodles.
Serve with lime wedges and chili for extra flavor.

name: Chè Chuối (Banana Sweet Soup)
description: A classic Vietnamese dessert made with bananas, tapioca pearls, coconut milk, and peanuts.

instructions.step: Soak tapioca pearls in warm water for 30 minutes.
Peel and slice the bananas into ½-inch thick rounds.
In a pot, combine water and tapioca pearls. Bring to a boil, then reduce heat and simmer until the pearls are translucent, about 15-20 minutes. Stir occasionally to prevent sticking.
Add the sugar and salt to the pot. Stir until dissolved.
Gently add the sliced bananas and coconut milk to the pot. Bring to a simmer and cook for about 5-10 minutes, or until the bananas are slightly softened but still holding their shape.
Stir in the vanilla extract.
Serve warm or chilled, garnished with crushed roasted peanuts.

name: Cá Lóc Hấp Bầu (Steamed Snakehead Fish with Gourd)
description: A traditional Vietnamese dish where snakehead fish is steamed inside a gourd, resulting in a flavorful and tender dish.

instructions.step: Soak dried shiitake mushrooms in warm water for 30 minutes, then slice thinly.
Clean the snakehead fish thoroughly. You can optionally fillet the fish or leave it whole.
Cut off the top of the gourd and scoop out the seeds and some of the flesh, creating a cavity to hold the fish.
Stuff the gourd cavity with the fish, sliced ginger, shiitake mushrooms, and green onions.
Season the fish inside the gourd with fish sauce, soy sauce, sugar, and pepper.
Place the gourd in a steamer basket. Add enough water to the steamer and bring to a boil.
Steam the gourd with the fish for 25-30 minutes, or until the fish is cooked through.  Check for doneness by inserting a fork into the fish; it should flake easily.
Carefully remove the gourd from the steamer. Garnish with fresh cilantro.
Serve hot. You can eat the fish and the cooked gourd flesh.

name: Bún Cá Chua (Sour Fish Noodle Soup)
description: A flavorful Vietnamese noodle soup with a tangy tomato broth, crispy fried fish, and fresh herbs.

instructions.step: Prepare the fish: Cut the fish fillets into bite-sized pieces, marinate with a pinch of salt, pepper, and turmeric powder for 15 minutes.
Fry the fish: Heat vegetable oil in a pan, fry the fish pieces until golden brown and crispy. Set aside.
Prepare the broth: In a pot, sauté minced garlic and shallots until fragrant. Add diced tomatoes and cook until softened.
Add liquid: Pour in water, add tamarind pulp (soaked in warm water and strained for its juice), fish sauce, and sugar. Bring to a boil, then reduce heat and simmer for 15 minutes.
Adjust seasoning: Taste the broth and adjust seasoning (fish sauce, sugar, salt) to your preference. It should be sour, sweet, and savory.
Assemble the soup: Cook rice noodles according to package directions. Drain well.
Serve: Divide cooked noodles into bowls, top with crispy fried fish, bean sprouts, pineapple chunks, scallions, dill, and mint. Ladle the hot broth over the ingredients.
Enjoy: Serve immediately and enjoy!

name: Bánh Giò (Steamed Rice Cake with Pork)
description: Traditional Vietnamese steamed rice cake filled with savory pork and wood ear mushrooms.

instructions.step: Soak dried wood ear mushrooms in warm water until softened. Chop finely.
Finely chop shallots.
In a bowl, combine ground pork, chopped wood ear mushrooms, shallots, fish sauce, salt, and pepper. Mix well and set aside.
In a large pot, whisk together rice flour, tapioca starch, salt, and water until smooth.
Cook the rice flour mixture over medium heat, stirring constantly to prevent lumps, until it thickens into a smooth paste. This may take about 15-20 minutes.
Heat cooking oil in a pan over medium heat. Add the pork mixture and cook until browned and cooked through. Set aside.
Prepare banana leaves by wiping them clean and lightly greasing them with cooking oil. Cut into suitable sizes for wrapping.

Place a spoonful of the rice flour mixture onto a banana leaf. Make a well in the center and fill it with the cooked pork mixture. Top with another spoonful of the rice flour mixture to cover the filling.
Wrap the banana leaf around the filling, shaping it into a cone or pyramid shape. Secure with kitchen twine.
Steam the wrapped bánh giò in a steamer for about 90 minutes, or until the rice cake is cooked through.
Let cool slightly before serving. Serve warm.

name: Gỏi Tép (Tiny Shrimp Salad)
description: A refreshing and flavorful Vietnamese salad with tiny shrimp, herbs, and a tangy dressing.

instructions.step: Blanch the tiny shrimp in boiling water for 1-2 minutes until cooked through. Drain and set aside.
Julienne the carrot and green mango into thin strips.
Thinly slice the red onion.
In a large bowl, combine the blanched shrimp, carrot, green mango, and red onion.
Prepare the dressing: In a small bowl, whisk together fish sauce, lime juice, sugar, and minced garlic. If using, finely chop the chili and add to the dressing.
Pour the dressing over the salad and toss gently to combine.
Add the Vietnamese mint and roasted peanuts. Toss lightly.
Serve immediately and enjoy!

name: Cơm Gà Hội An (Hoi An Chicken Rice)
description: A flavorful and aromatic rice dish from Hoi An, Vietnam, featuring turmeric-infused rice and tender shredded chicken.

instructions.step: Rinse the rice thoroughly until the water runs clear. Add rice, chicken broth, turmeric powder, and a pinch of salt to a rice cooker. Cook according to the rice cooker's instructions.
While the rice is cooking, boil the chicken thighs with a piece of ginger and a pinch of salt until cooked through (about 20-25 minutes). Let cool slightly, then shred the chicken meat.
Mince garlic and shallots. Finely chop the red chili (optional).
Prepare the dipping sauce by combining fish sauce, lime juice, minced garlic, chopped chili (optional), and a little sugar (optional). Adjust to taste.
In a pan, heat cooking oil over medium heat. Saute minced garlic and shallots until fragrant.
Mix the sauteed garlic and shallots with the shredded chicken.
Serve the turmeric rice topped with the shredded chicken mixture, fresh mint, fresh coriander, and a side of the dipping sauce.
Enjoy!

name: Mắm Tôm Chua (Fermented Shrimp Paste)
description: A popular Vietnamese fermented shrimp dish with a sweet, sour, and spicy flavor, perfect as a side dish or served with rice and vegetables.

instructions.step: Clean the shrimp, devein, and optionally lightly steam or blanch them for a short time until slightly cooked but still tender. Drain and let cool.
Finely chop the galangal, garlic, and chili.
In a large bowl, combine the chopped galangal, garlic, chili, sugar, fish sauce, and lime juice. Mix well to create the sauce.
Add the cooked shrimp, cooked rice, and chopped pineapple to the sauce. Mix gently but thoroughly.
Optionally add roasted rice powder and mix. This will thicken the sauce and add a nutty flavor.
Transfer the mixture to a clean glass jar or container. Press down gently to remove air pockets.

Seal the container tightly and let it ferment at room temperature for 2-5 days, depending on the temperature and desired level of fermentation. Check daily for taste and adjust the fermentation time accordingly.
Once fermented to your liking, refrigerate the Mắm Tôm Chua to slow down the fermentation process.
Serve as a side dish with rice, fresh herbs, and vegetables like cucumbers, lettuce, and bean sprouts.

name: Lẩu Nướng (Grill and Hot Pot Combo)
description: A delicious and interactive Vietnamese meal featuring both grilling and hot pot cooking.

ingredients.name: Squid, cleaned and sliced into rings

instructions.step: Prepare the Marinade: In a bowl, combine minced lemongrass, garlic, ginger, fish sauce, soy sauce, honey, sesame oil, and chili flakes. Mix well.
Marinate the Meats: Marinate the beef, pork, and chicken separately with the marinade for at least 30 minutes.
Prepare the Hot Pot Broth: Combine chicken and beef broth in a hot pot. Bring to a simmer.
Arrange the Ingredients: Arrange the marinated meats, seafood, vegetables, and mushrooms on separate plates for easy access.
Cook the Lẩu Nướng: Place the grill plate on top of the hot pot. Grill the meats until cooked through.
Add Ingredients to Hot Pot: Add the vegetables, mushrooms, and seafood to the hot pot broth. Cook until tender.
Serve and Enjoy: Serve the grilled meats and hot pot ingredients with rice noodles. Enjoy with your favorite dipping sauces (e.g., soy sauce with chili, fish sauce with lime).
Continue Cooking: Replenish the broth and ingredients as needed to continue the Lẩu Nướng experience.

name: Bánh Tét Chuối (Banana Sticky Rice Cake)
description: A traditional Vietnamese sticky rice cake filled with banana and wrapped in banana leaves, perfect for Tet (Lunar New Year) or any special occasion.

instructions.step: Wash the glutinous rice thoroughly and soak in water for at least 4 hours, or preferably overnight.
Drain the rice well and mix with salt and sugar.
Peel the bananas and cut them in half lengthwise. If the bananas are very large, you can cut them into smaller pieces.
Prepare the banana leaves by cleaning them and wiping them dry. You may need to soften them by briefly passing them over a low flame or in hot water to prevent them from tearing.
To assemble the cake, lay down a banana leaf. Place a layer of glutinous rice on the leaf, then arrange the banana pieces in the center. Top with another layer of glutinous rice.

Shape the cake into a cylindrical or rectangular shape. Fold the banana leaves tightly around the filling, securing the ends with kitchen twine or rubber bands. The wrapping should be tight to prevent water from seeping in during cooking.
Place the wrapped cakes in a large pot and cover with water. Make sure the cakes are fully submerged.

Bring the water to a boil, then reduce the heat and simmer for 3-4 hours, or until the rice is cooked through. Check the water level periodically and add more if necessary to ensure the cakes remain submerged.
Once cooked, remove the cakes from the pot and let them cool slightly before unwrapping.
Serve the Bánh Tét Chuối warm or at room temperature. Enjoy!

name: Gà Hấp Lá Chanh (Chicken Steamed with Lime Leaves)
description: A classic Vietnamese dish featuring tender, aromatic chicken infused with the zesty fragrance of lime leaves.

instructions.step: Rinse the chicken thoroughly inside and out. Pat dry with paper towels.
Stuff the cavity of the chicken with half of the lime leaves, ginger slices, and scallions.
Rub the chicken skin with salt and pepper.
Place the chicken on a heatproof plate or steamer basket.
Scatter the remaining lime leaves, ginger, and scallions around the chicken.
Steam the chicken over high heat for 30 minutes, or until the internal temperature reaches 165°F (74°C).
While the chicken is steaming, prepare the dipping sauce by combining fish sauce, lime juice, and sugar in a small bowl. Adjust to taste.
Once the chicken is cooked, carefully remove it from the steamer and let it rest for 10 minutes before carving.
Serve the chicken hot with the dipping sauce and steamed rice.

name: Canh Khổ Qua Nhồi Thịt (Stuffed Bitter Melon Soup)
description: A traditional Vietnamese soup featuring bitter melon stuffed with seasoned ground pork. The bitterness of the melon is balanced by the savory filling, creating a unique and flavorful broth.

instructions.step: Soak wood ear mushrooms and glass noodles in warm water until softened. Drain and chop finely.
Prepare the filling: In a bowl, combine ground pork, chopped mushrooms, glass noodles, minced shallots, fish sauce, soy sauce, pepper, and sugar. Mix well.

Prepare the bitter melons: Cut the bitter melons in half lengthwise. Scoop out the seeds and pith. Blanch the bitter melon in boiling salted water for 2-3 minutes to reduce bitterness. Drain and rinse with cold water.
Stuff the bitter melons: Fill each bitter melon half with the pork mixture, packing it tightly.
Cook the soup: In a large pot, bring chicken broth or water to a boil. Gently add the stuffed bitter melons.
Reduce heat and simmer for about 45-60 minutes, or until the bitter melon is tender and the pork is cooked through. Skim off any foam that rises to the surface.
Season with salt to taste. Garnish with chopped scallions before serving.

name: Bún Mắm Nêm (Vermicelli with Fermented Fish Sauce)
description: A flavorful and pungent Vietnamese noodle dish with fermented fish sauce, roasted pork, fresh herbs, and vegetables.

instructions.step: Prepare the Mắm Nêm sauce: In a mortar and pestle, crush garlic and chili pepper. Add fermented fish sauce, chopped pineapple, sugar, and lime juice. Mix well and adjust to taste.
Prepare the vegetables and herbs: Wash and shred lettuce, wash bean sprouts, slice cucumber thinly, and chop mint and Vietnamese coriander.
Cook the vermicelli noodles according to package directions. Drain and rinse with cold water.
Slice the roasted pork belly into thin pieces.

Assemble the dish: In a bowl, place a portion of vermicelli noodles. Top with lettuce, bean sprouts, cucumber, roasted pork belly, pickled carrots and daikon, mint, Vietnamese coriander, and crushed peanuts.
Pour the Mắm Nêm sauce over the ingredients. Serve immediately.

name: Chè Bắp (Corn Sweet Soup)
description: A classic Vietnamese sweet soup made with sweet corn, glutinous rice, and coconut milk. This dessert is warm, comforting, and subtly sweet.

instructions.step: Rinse the glutinous rice and soak it in water for at least 30 minutes.
If using frozen corn, thaw it slightly. If using fresh corn, shave the kernels off the cob.
In a large pot, combine the water, glutinous rice, and corn kernels. Bring to a boil, then reduce heat and simmer for about 20 minutes, or until the rice is tender and the corn is cooked.
Add the sugar and salt to the pot. Stir until the sugar is dissolved.
In a separate saucepan, gently heat the coconut milk over low heat. Do not boil.
If using tapioca pearls, cook according to package instructions.
Ladle the corn soup into bowls. Drizzle with warm coconut milk and optionally add cooked tapioca pearls. Serve warm.

name: Bánh Rán (Vietnamese Fried Doughnut)
description: Crispy on the outside, chewy and sweet on the inside, these Vietnamese fried doughnuts are a delightful treat.

instructions.step: Prepare the dough: In a large bowl, combine glutinous rice flour, cooked rice, and sugar. Gradually add warm water and vanilla extract, mixing until a soft and slightly sticky dough forms. Knead for 5-7 minutes until smooth.
Prepare the filling: If using store bought mung bean paste, just portion it into 12 equal balls. Otherwise, prepare your mung bean paste, cook and mash. Portion into 12 equal balls.

Assemble the doughnuts: Take a small portion of the dough (about 30g) and flatten it into a disc. Place a mung bean ball in the center and wrap the dough around it, sealing the edges tightly. Roll into a smooth ball.
Coat with sesame seeds: Roll each dough ball in a bowl of sesame seeds, making sure they are evenly coated.
Fry the doughnuts: Heat vegetable oil in a deep pot or frying pan over medium heat. Carefully place the dough balls into the hot oil, a few at a time, making sure not to overcrowd the pot.

Cook until golden brown: Fry the doughnuts for 5-7 minutes, turning them frequently, until they are golden brown and crispy on all sides. Use a slotted spoon to remove them from the oil and place them on a paper towel-lined plate to drain excess oil.
Serve warm: Enjoy Bánh Rán warm as a snack or dessert.

name: Cá Kho Dừa (Fish Braised in Coconut Juice)
description: A classic Vietnamese dish featuring fish simmered in a savory-sweet coconut caramel sauce.

instructions.step: Prepare the caramel sauce: In a pot, heat sugar over medium heat until it melts and turns a deep amber color. Be careful not to burn it.
Add oil, garlic, and shallots: Add vegetable oil to the caramelized sugar, followed by minced garlic and shallots. Sauté until fragrant.
Add fish sauce, soy sauce, and pepper: Stir in fish sauce, soy sauce, and black pepper.
Add coconut juice: Pour in the coconut juice and bring to a simmer.
Add fish: Gently place the fish steaks into the simmering sauce. Make sure the fish is submerged.
Simmer: Reduce heat to low, cover, and simmer for about 45-60 minutes, or until the fish is cooked through and the sauce has thickened. Occasionally spoon sauce over the fish to baste.
Add chili: Add sliced red chili for heat (optional) during the last 10 minutes of cooking.
Serve: Serve hot with steamed rice.

name: Gỏi Cá Mai Nha Trang (Nha Trang Fish Salad)
description: A refreshing and flavorful Vietnamese fish salad from Nha Trang, featuring fresh mai fish, herbs, and a tangy dressing.

instructions.step: Prepare the fish: Gently rinse the mai fish fillets and pat them completely dry.  Marinate them in rice vinegar for 5-10 minutes. This will slightly "cook" the fish. Drain and discard the vinegar.
Make the dressing: In a bowl, whisk together lime juice, fish sauce, sugar, minced garlic, and chili (if using). Adjust the quantities to your preference.
Combine ingredients: In a large bowl, combine the marinated fish, green mango, cucumber, carrot and fresh herbs.
Dress the salad: Pour the dressing over the fish and vegetables. Toss gently to combine.
Garnish and serve: Sprinkle crushed roasted peanuts, fried shallots, and roasted sesame seeds over the salad. Serve immediately.

name: Cơm Nắm (Sticky Rice Ball)
description: Simple and satisfying Vietnamese sticky rice balls, perfect for a quick meal or snack.

instructions.step: Soak the glutinous rice in water for at least 4 hours, or preferably overnight.
Drain the rice and steam it in a steamer for about 30 minutes, or until cooked through and sticky.
While the rice is steaming, prepare the pork belly. Dice it into small pieces.
Soak the dried shrimp in warm water for 15 minutes, then drain and chop finely.
Mince the shallots.
Heat cooking oil in a pan over medium heat. Add the minced shallots and sauté until golden brown and fragrant.
Add the diced pork belly and dried shrimp to the pan. Cook until the pork is cooked through and slightly browned.
Season with fish sauce, sugar, and black pepper. Cook for another minute, stirring constantly.
Remove the rice from the steamer and let it cool slightly.
Take a handful of rice and flatten it in your palm. Place a spoonful of the pork and shrimp filling in the center.
Shape the rice around the filling to form a ball. Repeat with the remaining rice and filling.
Serve the Cơm Nắm warm or at room temperature. Enjoy!

name: Mực Xào Hành Tây (Squid Stir-fried with Onions)
description: A quick and flavorful Vietnamese stir-fry featuring tender squid and sweet onions.

instructions.step: In a bowl, marinate the squid with fish sauce, sugar, pepper, and oyster sauce (if using) for 10 minutes.
Heat oil in a wok or large skillet over high heat.
Add minced garlic and stir-fry until fragrant (about 30 seconds).
Add sliced onions and bell pepper (if using) and stir-fry until softened (about 2-3 minutes).
Add the marinated squid to the wok and stir-fry quickly until the squid is cooked through and turns opaque (about 2-3 minutes). Be careful not to overcook the squid, as it will become tough.
Garnish with chopped green onions and cilantro (if using).
Serve immediately with steamed rice.

name: Lẩu Bò (Beef Hot Pot)
description: A comforting and flavorful Vietnamese hot pot with beef and a variety of vegetables.

instructions.step: Rinse the beef bones and oxtail (if using) under cold water.
In a large pot, combine the beef bones, oxtail (if using), and water. Bring to a boil, then reduce heat and simmer for at least 1 hour, skimming off any foam that rises to the surface.
Add the lemongrass, ginger, onion, star anise, and cinnamon stick to the pot. Continue to simmer for another 30 minutes.
Strain the broth through a fine-mesh sieve, discarding the solids.
Return the broth to the pot and season with fish sauce, sugar, salt, and MSG (if using). Bring to a simmer.
Set up a portable burner or hot plate on your dining table. Place the pot of broth on the burner.
Arrange the thinly sliced beef, rice noodles, water spinach, bean sprouts, enoki mushrooms, and tofu around the pot.
Bring the broth to a boil. Let everyone add the ingredients they want to cook into the broth. Cook until the ingredients are cooked through.
Serve the cooked ingredients with the broth in individual bowls. Add Chili oil if desired
Enjoy the Lẩu Bò hot pot!

name: Bún Ngan (Duck Vermicelli Soup)
description: A comforting and flavorful Vietnamese duck noodle soup.

instructions.step: Rinse the duck thoroughly. Boil the duck in a large pot with ginger and a pinch of salt for about 1.5 hours, or until tender. Remove the duck and let it cool.

While the duck is cooking, soak the dried shiitake mushrooms and dried bamboo shoots in warm water until softened. Rinse and slice the mushrooms. Boil the bamboo shoots for 10 minutes to remove any bitterness, then slice them thinly.
Debone the duck, reserving the bones and meat separately. Slice the duck meat into bite-sized pieces.
Return the duck bones to the pot with the broth. Add the soaked mushrooms and bamboo shoots. Season with fish sauce, rock sugar, salt, and pepper. Simmer for another 30 minutes.
Cook the vermicelli noodles according to package directions. Drain and divide among bowls.
Top the noodles with sliced duck meat, green onions, and cilantro.
Ladle the hot broth over the noodles and duck. Serve with lime wedges and extra chili if desired.

name: Chè Hạt Sen Đậu Xanh (Lotus Seed and Mung Bean Sweet Soup)
description: A traditional Vietnamese sweet soup made with lotus seeds, mung beans, and coconut milk. A light and refreshing dessert, perfect for a warm day.

instructions.step: Rinse the dried lotus seeds and mung beans thoroughly. Soak them in separate bowls with water for at least 4 hours, or preferably overnight.
Drain the lotus seeds and mung beans. Remove the green germ from the lotus seeds, if desired (this can reduce bitterness).
In a large pot, combine the soaked lotus seeds and 1000 ml of water. Bring to a boil, then reduce heat and simmer for 30-40 minutes, or until the lotus seeds are tender.
Add the soaked mung beans and pandan leaves (if using) to the pot. Continue to simmer for another 20-30 minutes, or until the mung beans are soft and have burst.
Stir in the sugar and vanilla extract (if using). Adjust the sweetness to your liking. Simmer for a few more minutes until the sugar is dissolved.
Remove the pandan leaves (if using).
In a separate saucepan, gently heat the coconut milk over low heat. Do not boil.
To serve, ladle the lotus seed and mung bean soup into bowls. Drizzle with warm coconut milk.
Serve warm or chilled.

name: Bánh Tráng Trộn (Mixed Rice Paper Salad)
description: A popular Vietnamese street food snack made with rice paper, dried shrimp, beef jerky, quail eggs, herbs, and a tangy sauce.

instructions.step: Prepare the sauce: Mix soy sauce, tamarind paste, sugar, and water in a small bowl. Adjust to taste.
Cut the rice paper into thin strips.
In a large bowl, combine the rice paper strips, dried shrimp, beef jerky, sliced quail eggs, shredded green mango, and chopped laksa leaves.
Pour the prepared sauce over the ingredients in the bowl.
Add chili oil to your preferred spice level.
Toss everything together until well combined.
Sprinkle with fried shallots and roasted peanuts.
Serve immediately and enjoy!

name: Cá Lóc Nướng Mắm Nêm (Grilled Snakehead with Fermented Fish Sauce)
description: A classic Vietnamese dish featuring grilled snakehead fish served with flavorful fermented fish sauce.

instructions.step: Prepare the fish: Clean and scale the snakehead fish thoroughly. Pat it dry.
Prepare the mắm nêm sauce: In a small bowl, combine the fermented fish sauce, minced pineapple, minced garlic, chopped chili, sugar, and lime juice. Mix well.
Grill the fish: Preheat your grill to medium heat. Lightly grease the grill grates. Grill the fish for about 15-20 minutes per side, or until cooked through and the skin is slightly charred.

Serve: Serve the grilled snakehead fish with rice paper, fresh herbs, cucumber, and vermicelli noodles. Let diners wrap the fish and vegetables in the rice paper and dip it into the mắm nêm sauce before eating.

name: Gà Xào Hạt Điều (Cashew Nut Chicken Stir-fry)
description: A classic Vietnamese stir-fry featuring tender chicken, crunchy cashews, and colorful vegetables in a savory sauce.

instructions.step: Cut chicken breast into bite-sized pieces. Marinate with soy sauce, rice wine, cornstarch, and a pinch of salt for at least 15 minutes.
Prepare the vegetables: Dice the bell peppers and onion. Mince the garlic. Cut the dried chilies in half (remove seeds for less heat). Chop the scallions.
In a small bowl, mix soy sauce, oyster sauce, sugar, and a tablespoon of water to create the sauce.
Heat vegetable oil in a wok or large skillet over medium-high heat. Add the marinated chicken and stir-fry until cooked through and lightly browned.
Remove the chicken from the wok and set aside.
Add a little more oil to the wok. Stir-fry the garlic and dried chilies until fragrant.
Add the onion and bell peppers and stir-fry until slightly softened.
Return the chicken to the wok. Pour in the sauce and stir-fry until everything is well coated.
Add the cashew nuts and stir-fry for another minute.
Garnish with chopped scallions and serve hot with steamed rice.

name: Canh Rau Muống (Water Spinach Soup)
description: A simple and refreshing Vietnamese soup made with water spinach (morning glory) and a flavorful broth.

instructions.step: Wash the water spinach thoroughly and cut into 2-inch pieces.
Peel and thinly slice the shallots.
Bring water to a boil in a pot.
Add the sliced shallots to the boiling water and cook for 2-3 minutes until fragrant.
Add the water spinach to the pot and cook until the spinach is tender, about 3-5 minutes.
Season with fish sauce, salt, sugar, and pepper. Adjust to taste.
Simmer for another minute and serve hot.

name: Bún Thịt Nướng Chả Giò (Grilled Pork Vermicelli with Fried Rolls)
description: A flavorful Vietnamese noodle dish featuring grilled pork, crispy fried spring rolls, fresh herbs, and a tangy dipping sauce.

instructions.step: Prepare the pork marinade: Mince lemongrass, garlic, and shallots. Combine with fish sauce, soy sauce, sugar, and pepper. Marinate pork for at least 30 minutes.
Make the spring roll filling: Soak wood ear mushrooms in warm water. Chop finely. Combine ground pork, chopped shrimp, chopped carrots, and chopped mushrooms.
Assemble and fry the spring rolls: Fill spring roll wrappers with the pork mixture and roll tightly. Fry in vegetable oil until golden brown and crispy.
Grill the pork: Grill marinated pork over medium heat until cooked through and slightly charred.
Prepare the noodles: Cook rice vermicelli according to package directions.
Assemble the dish: In a bowl, place rice vermicelli noodles. Top with grilled pork, fried spring rolls, bean sprouts, lettuce, mint, and cilantro. Drizzle with nuoc cham dipping sauce.
Serve immediately and enjoy!

name: Chè Khoai Mì (Cassava Sweet Soup)
description: A classic Vietnamese dessert featuring tender cassava cooked in sweet coconut milk.

instructions.step: Peel the cassava and remove the fibrous core. Grate or shred the cassava finely.
Rinse the grated cassava thoroughly with water to remove excess starch. Squeeze out excess water.
In a pot, combine the grated cassava, coconut milk, sugar, and salt. Add pandan leaves if using.
Bring the mixture to a simmer over medium heat, stirring constantly to prevent sticking.
Cook for about 30-40 minutes, or until the cassava is tender and the soup has thickened. Stir frequently.
If using tapioca pearls, cook them separately according to package instructions.
Remove from heat and stir in the vanilla extract.
Serve warm or chilled, garnished with cooked tapioca pearls (if using).

name: Bánh Tét Lá Cẩm (Sticky Rice Cake with Magenta Plant)
description: A savory Vietnamese sticky rice cake with a beautiful purple hue and a rich, savory filling. This traditional dish is often enjoyed during Tet (Vietnamese New Year).

instructions.step: Soak the glutinous rice in water overnight. Add chopped magenta plant leaves to the rice and let sit for 2-3 hours to absorb color. Drain well.
Soak the mung beans in water for at least 4 hours. Steam until soft and mash.
Cut the pork belly into cubes. Marinate with salt, pepper, and sugar.
Sauté the dried shallots until golden brown. Mix the mashed mung beans with fried shallots.

On a banana leaf, spread a layer of glutinous rice, then a layer of mung bean paste, followed by a piece of pork belly, and another layer of mung bean paste, and finally cover with another layer of rice.
Fold the banana leaves tightly to form a cylinder. Secure with string.
Place the wrapped cakes in a large pot and cover with water. Bring to a boil, then simmer for 3-4 hours, or until the rice is cooked through.
Remove the cakes from the pot and let them cool slightly before serving. Unwrap and enjoy!

name: Cá Hồi Nướng Mọi (Grilled Salmon)
description: Simple and flavorful grilled salmon, Vietnamese style.

instructions.step: Mince garlic and chop green onion.
In a small bowl, combine fish sauce, sugar, minced garlic, black pepper, and chopped green onion.
Rub the mixture onto the salmon fillets. Let it marinate for at least 10 minutes.
Preheat grill to medium-high heat. Lightly oil the grill grates.
Place salmon fillets skin-side down on the grill and cook for 5-7 minutes, or until the skin is crispy and the fish is cooked through.
Flip the salmon and cook for another 2-3 minutes, or until it is cooked to your desired doneness.
Squeeze lime juice over the salmon before serving.

name: Gỏi Cuốn Tôm Thịt (Shrimp & Pork Fresh Spring Rolls)
description: Fresh and flavorful Vietnamese spring rolls filled with shrimp, pork, vegetables, and herbs, served with a peanut dipping sauce.

instructions.step: Prepare all ingredients: cook noodles, shrimp, and pork. Chop vegetables and herbs.
Soften rice paper wrappers one at a time by dipping them in warm water for a few seconds until pliable.
Lay the softened rice paper on a flat surface.
Arrange a lettuce leaf, a few slices of pork, shrimp, rice vermicelli, mint, cilantro, bean sprouts, carrots, and cucumber in the center of the rice paper.
Fold the sides of the rice paper over the filling, then roll tightly from the bottom up, like a burrito.
Repeat with the remaining ingredients.
Serve immediately with peanut dipping sauce.

name: Cơm Hến (Baby Clam Rice)
description: A flavorful and comforting Vietnamese rice dish with baby clams, crispy pork skin, herbs, and chili.

instructions.step: Soak baby clams in salted water for 30 minutes to remove sand. Rinse thoroughly.
Boil the clams until they open. Remove the clams from the shells and set aside. Reserve the clam broth.
Cut pork belly into small cubes and fry until crispy. Set aside.
In a pan, heat vegetable oil and sauté minced shallots, garlic, and ginger until fragrant.
Add shrimp paste and cook for 1 minute. Then add the clams and stir-fry for another 2 minutes.
Season with fish sauce, chili sauce, sugar, and salt. Add a little of the clam broth if needed.
In a bowl, combine cooked rice, clam mixture, crispy pork belly, pork rinds, peanuts, sesame seeds, mint, coriander, and spring onions.
Squeeze lime juice over the dish. Mix well and serve immediately.

name: Mực Hấp Sả (Steamed Squid with Lemongrass)
description: A classic Vietnamese dish where tender squid is steamed with fragrant lemongrass and ginger, resulting in a light and refreshing seafood delight.

instructions.step: Prepare the squid: Clean the squid thoroughly and score the bodies lightly in a crosshatch pattern. This helps with even cooking and presentation.
Prepare the aromatics: Slice lemongrass into thin rounds. Slice ginger into thin rounds or julienne. If using, slice the chili into thin rounds.
Arrange the aromatics: Place half of the lemongrass and ginger at the bottom of a steamer basket or heat-safe dish.
Place the squid: Arrange the squid on top of the lemongrass and ginger.
Add remaining aromatics: Scatter the remaining lemongrass, ginger, and chili (if using) over the squid.
Steam the squid: Steam the squid for 15-20 minutes, or until it is cooked through and opaque.
Prepare the dipping sauce: While the squid is steaming, prepare the dipping sauce by combining fish sauce, sugar, lime juice, chopped green onion, salt, and pepper in a small bowl. Adjust to taste.
Serve: Once the squid is cooked, remove it from the steamer and arrange it on a serving platter. Serve immediately with the dipping sauce.

name: Lẩu Cá Lăng (Catfish Hot Pot)
description: A flavorful and aromatic Vietnamese hot pot featuring tender catfish, fresh herbs, and a tangy broth.

instructions.step: Prepare the ingredients: Slice the catfish fillets, pineapple, and tomatoes. Chop the lemongrass, ginger, garlic, and shallots. Wash the bean sprouts, okra, and herbs.

Make the broth: In a large pot, heat the vegetable oil over medium heat. Add the chopped lemongrass, ginger, garlic, and shallots and sauté until fragrant. Add the tomatoes and cook until softened. Add the water and tamarind paste. Bring to a boil, then reduce heat and simmer for 15 minutes.
Season the broth: Season the broth with fish sauce and sugar. Adjust the seasoning to taste. Add chili peppers if desired.
Assemble the hot pot: Transfer the broth to a hot pot. Arrange the catfish fillets, pineapple, bean sprouts, okra, and herbs around the hot pot.
Cook the hot pot: Bring the broth to a simmer. Cook the catfish and vegetables until cooked through. Serve immediately with rice noodles or rice.

name: Bún Riêu Cua Đồng (Crab Vermicelli Soup)
description: A flavorful and aromatic Vietnamese soup with fresh crab, tomatoes, and vermicelli noodles.

instructions.step: Clean the freshwater crab thoroughly. Separate the crab roe and reserve. Grind the crab meat and strain with water. Reserve the crab broth.
Sauté chopped tomatoes in annatto oil until softened. Add ground pork and cook until browned.
In a large pot, combine the crab broth, sautéed tomatoes and pork, fermented shrimp paste, dried shrimp, salt, sugar, and fish sauce. Bring to a boil and simmer for 30 minutes.
Add the crab roe to the soup and cook until it solidifies.
Add fried tofu to the soup.
Cook vermicelli noodles according to package instructions.
Serve the soup hot with vermicelli noodles, bean sprouts, shredded water spinach, green onions, and lime wedges.

name: Chè Sương Sáo (Grass Jelly Sweet Soup)
description: A refreshing and cooling Vietnamese dessert with grass jelly, coconut milk, and tapioca pearls.

instructions.step: Cook tapioca pearls according to package instructions until translucent. Rinse with cold water and set aside.
Cut grass jelly into bite-sized cubes.
In a saucepan, combine coconut milk, water, sugar, and pandan leaves. Bring to a simmer over medium heat, stirring until sugar is dissolved. Remove pandan leaves.
Let the coconut milk mixture cool completely.
In serving bowls, arrange grass jelly cubes and cooked tapioca pearls.
Pour the cooled coconut milk mixture over the grass jelly and tapioca pearls.
Add ice and serve immediately.

name: Bánh Cốm (Young Rice Cake)
description: A traditional Vietnamese sweet made from young rice, mung beans, and coconut, offering a chewy and subtly sweet flavor.

instructions.step: Soak the mung beans in water for at least 4 hours, or overnight. Steam until tender, about 20-25 minutes.

Mash the steamed mung beans until smooth. Mix with sugar, coconut milk, and vanilla extract. Cook over low heat, stirring constantly, until the mixture thickens and forms a paste. Let cool completely.
Wash and dry the cốm. Soak in coconut milk for about 30 minutes to soften.
Steam the soaked cốm with pandan leaves for about 20-25 minutes, or until tender and chewy. Remove from heat and let cool slightly.
Divide the mung bean paste into 8 equal portions. Shape each portion into a ball.
Divide the steamed cốm into 8 equal portions. Flatten each portion and wrap it around a mung bean ball, sealing the edges tightly.
Wrap each bánh cốm in banana leaves (optional).
Serve at room temperature.

name: Cá Sấu Nướng (Grilled Crocodile)
description: Grilled crocodile, a unique and flavorful dish popular in some parts of Southeast Asia.

instructions.step: Prepare the crocodile meat: Cut into desired pieces (steaks or chunks) and pound lightly to tenderize.
Make the marinade: In a mortar and pestle (or food processor), crush the lemongrass, garlic, and shallots into a paste.
Combine marinade ingredients: In a bowl, mix the lemongrass mixture with fish sauce, soy sauce, honey, chili flakes, black pepper, and lime juice.
Marinate the crocodile: Coat the crocodile meat thoroughly with the marinade and let it sit for at least 30 minutes (or up to 2 hours in the refrigerator).
Prepare the grill: Preheat a grill to medium-high heat.
Grill the crocodile: Grill the crocodile meat for about 5-7 minutes per side, or until cooked through and slightly charred. Adjust cooking time depending on the thickness of the meat.
Rest the meat: Let the grilled crocodile rest for a few minutes before serving.
Serve: Serve hot with fresh herbs (mint, cilantro), lime wedges, and rice or noodles.

name: Gà Tiềm Ớt Hiểm (Chicken Stewed with Chili)
description: A warming and flavorful Vietnamese chicken stew with a spicy kick from chili peppers. Perfect for a comforting meal.

instructions.step: Rinse the chicken thighs and pat them dry.
Toast the dried red chilies in a dry pan over medium heat for a minute or two until fragrant. Be careful not to burn them.
Peel and slice the ginger and shallots. Mince the garlic.
In a large pot or Dutch oven, combine the chicken thighs, water, chicken broth, toasted chilies, ginger, garlic, shallots, fish sauce, sugar, soy sauce, and black peppercorns.
Bring the mixture to a boil, then reduce the heat to low, cover, and simmer for 45 minutes.
Add the mushrooms and red dates. Continue to simmer for another 15 minutes, or until the chicken is tender and cooked through.
Taste and adjust seasoning as needed. Add more fish sauce or sugar to taste.
Serve hot with rice or noodles. Garnish with fresh cilantro or green onions if desired.

name: Canh Chua Tôm (Sour Shrimp Soup)
description: A flavorful and refreshing Vietnamese sour soup with shrimp, vegetables, and a tangy tamarind broth.

instructions.step: Soak tamarind pulp in 1/2 cup of warm water for 10 minutes. Strain the tamarind water, discarding the pulp.
Heat vegetable oil in a pot over medium heat. Add minced garlic and sliced shallot and sauté until fragrant.
Add tomatoes and cook for 2-3 minutes until softened.
Pour in water and bring to a boil.
Add tamarind water, fish sauce, and sugar. Stir to combine.
Add pineapple and okra to the pot and simmer for 5 minutes.
Add shrimp and cook until pink and cooked through, about 2-3 minutes.
Add bean sprouts and cook for 1 minute.
Remove from heat and stir in rice paddy herb and culantro.
Serve hot.

name: Bún Bò Nam Bộ (Southern Vietnamese Beef Noodle Salad)
description: A flavorful and refreshing Vietnamese noodle salad with marinated beef, fresh herbs, and a savory nước chấm dressing.

instructions.step: In a bowl, marinate the beef with lemongrass, garlic, soy sauce, fish sauce, sugar, and black pepper for at least 30 minutes.
Cook the rice vermicelli noodles according to package directions. Drain and rinse with cold water.
Heat vegetable oil in a skillet or wok over medium-high heat. Stir-fry the marinated beef until cooked through, about 2-3 minutes.
Prepare the Nước Chấm dipping sauce (recipe not included).
Assemble the salad: In a large bowl, combine the rice noodles, lettuce, cucumber, and bean sprouts.
Top with the stir-fried beef, mint leaves, cilantro leaves, roasted peanuts, and fried shallots.
Drizzle with Nước Chấm sauce and serve immediately.

name: Chè Chuối Nếp Nướng (Grilled Banana with Sticky Rice Sweet Soup)
description: A delicious Vietnamese dessert featuring grilled banana wrapped in sticky rice, simmered in a creamy coconut milk broth.

instructions.step: Soak the sticky rice in water for at least 4 hours, or preferably overnight.
Drain the soaked sticky rice and steam it until cooked through. This usually takes about 20-25 minutes.

While the sticky rice is cooking, peel the bananas.  Wrap each banana with a generous amount of cooked sticky rice, forming a log shape. Use banana leaves or parchment paper to secure the rice around the banana.
Grill the wrapped bananas over medium heat, turning occasionally, until the banana is heated through and the sticky rice is slightly golden brown and crispy. This should take about 10-15 minutes.
In a saucepan, combine the coconut milk, sugar, and salt. Bring to a simmer over medium heat, stirring occasionally to dissolve the sugar.
If using Pandan Leaves, tie them into a knot and add to the coconut milk mixture for added fragrance.
In a small bowl, dissolve the tapioca starch in 2 tablespoons of water. This is your slurry.
Slowly add the tapioca starch slurry to the simmering coconut milk, stirring constantly to prevent lumps. Cook until the sauce thickens slightly.
Remove the Pandan leaves from the sauce.
Add the vanilla extract to the coconut milk sauce and stir to combine.
To serve, slice the grilled banana and sticky rice into pieces. Place the slices in a bowl and pour the warm coconut milk sauce over them. Garnish with roasted peanuts.

name: Bánh Tráng Nướng Mỡ Hành (Rice Paper with Scallion Oil)
description: Vietnamese street food delight: grilled rice paper pizza topped with scallion oil and various savory ingredients.

instructions.step: Prepare the scallion oil: thinly slice the scallions and heat the vegetable oil in a small pan over medium heat. Add the scallions and cook until they become fragrant and slightly wilted. Remove from heat.
Place the rice paper on a grill or non-stick pan over low heat.
Quickly brush the rice paper with the scallion oil.
Crack the quail egg onto the rice paper and spread it evenly with the back of a spoon.
Sprinkle the dried shrimp over the egg.
Drizzle sriracha and mayonnaise over the top.
Grill for 2-3 minutes, or until the rice paper is crispy and the egg is cooked.
Fold in half or quarters if desired and serve immediately.

name: Cá Lóc Nướng Trui (Grilled Snakehead Fish on Stick)
description: A traditional Vietnamese dish where snakehead fish is grilled whole over an open flame, often wrapped in straw for added flavor.

instructions.step: Clean the snakehead fish thoroughly. You can descale it or leave the scales on, depending on your preference. Remove the gills and intestines.
Stuff the cavity of the fish with lemongrass, green onion, and ginger to infuse flavor.
Rub the outside of the fish with salt and pepper.
If using straw, wrap the fish loosely with dry rice straw. Secure with twine.

Grill the fish over an open flame (charcoal or wood fire is ideal) for about 30 minutes, turning frequently to ensure even cooking. The fish is done when the skin is charred and the flesh is cooked through.
Remove the straw (if used) and carefully remove the fish from the grill. The skin should be crispy and the inside moist.
Serve the fish whole with rice paper, fresh lettuce, mint, and dipping sauce (Nuoc Cham).
To eat, wrap a piece of fish, lettuce, and mint in rice paper and dip it in the sauce.
Enjoy!

name: Gỏi Cá Trích (Herring Fish Salad)
description: A refreshing and flavorful Vietnamese herring salad with fresh herbs, vegetables, and a tangy fish sauce dressing.

instructions.step: Thinly slice the herring fillets and marinate in rice vinegar for 15 minutes.
While the herring marinates, julienne the red onion, carrot, green mango, and cucumber.
Roughly chop the peanuts, mint, and coriander.
Prepare the fish sauce dressing by combining fish sauce, lime juice, sugar, minced garlic and chopped chili. Stir until sugar is dissolved.
Drain the rice vinegar from the herring and combine with the julienned vegetables, mint, coriander, and peanuts.
Pour the fish sauce dressing over the salad and toss gently to combine.
Serve immediately or chill for later.

name: Cơm Cháy Chà Bông (Crispy Rice with Pork Floss)
description: A popular Vietnamese street food consisting of crispy fried rice topped with savory pork floss, scallions, and a sweet and savory sauce.

instructions.step: Spread the cooked rice in a thin layer on a baking sheet or tray lined with parchment paper. Let it dry for at least 2 hours, or preferably overnight, in a cool, dry place. The drier the rice, the crispier it will be.
Heat cooking oil in a large wok or deep frying pan over medium-high heat.
Carefully slide a portion of the dried rice into the hot oil. Fry until golden brown and crispy, about 2-3 minutes per side. Be careful not to overcrowd the pan.
Remove the crispy rice from the oil and place on a wire rack or paper towels to drain excess oil.
While the rice is frying, prepare the sauce: In a small bowl, combine fish sauce, sugar, water, and chili garlic sauce (if using). Mix well until sugar is dissolved.
Once all the rice is fried, chop the scallions finely.
To assemble, place the crispy rice on a serving plate. Drizzle with the prepared sauce, then top with pork floss and chopped scallions.
Serve immediately and enjoy!

name: Mực Nướng Mật Ong (Honey Grilled Squid)
description: Vietnamese Honey Grilled Squid is a simple yet flavorful dish, perfect for a quick and delicious meal. The squid is marinated in a sweet and savory honey mixture, then grilled to perfection.

instructions.step: Clean the squid thoroughly. Score the squid lightly with a knife to help it absorb the marinade and prevent curling during grilling.
Mince garlic and shallots. In a bowl, combine honey, fish sauce, minced garlic, minced shallots, chili flakes, and black pepper. Mix well.
Marinate the squid in the honey mixture for at least 15 minutes.
Preheat grill to medium-high heat. Brush the grill grates with vegetable oil to prevent sticking.
Grill the squid for 3-5 minutes per side, or until cooked through and slightly charred. Be careful not to overcook, as squid can become tough.
Serve the grilled squid immediately with steamed rice or fresh vegetables. You can garnish with chopped cilantro or green onions.

name: Lẩu Gà Lá Giang (Chicken Hotpot with La Giang Leaves)
description: A sour and flavorful Vietnamese chicken hotpot featuring La Giang leaves for a unique taste.

instructions.step: Prepare Ingredients: Wash and chop chicken into smaller pieces. Roughly chop lemongrass and galangal. Mince garlic and shallots. Wash La Giang leaves thoroughly.
Sauté Aromatics: Heat cooking oil in a large pot. Add minced garlic, shallots, chopped lemongrass, and galangal. Sauté until fragrant.
Brown Chicken: Add chicken pieces to the pot and sauté until lightly browned.
Add Broth and Seasoning: Pour chicken broth into the pot. Add fish sauce, sugar, and salt. Bring to a boil, then reduce heat and simmer for 30 minutes, or until chicken is tender.
Add La Giang Leaves: Add La Giang leaves to the hotpot and simmer for another 5-10 minutes, or until the leaves are slightly wilted and the broth has a sour flavor.
Adjust Seasoning: Taste the broth and adjust seasoning as needed. Add more fish sauce for saltiness, sugar for sweetness, or chili for spiciness.
Serve: Serve hot in a hotpot or large bowl. Offer with rice noodles, mushrooms, tofu, and other dipping sauces as desired.

name: Bún Bò Cay (Spicy Beef Noodle Soup)
description: A flavorful and spicy Vietnamese beef noodle soup.

instructions.step: Parboil beef shank and beef bones for 5 minutes. Rinse and clean.
In a large pot, combine beef shank, beef bones, and water. Bring to a boil, then reduce heat and simmer for 1.5 hours.
Toast lemongrass and ginger until fragrant. Add to the pot.
In a small saucepan, heat vegetable oil and annatto seeds. Cook until oil turns red. Strain the oil and discard the seeds.
Add chili powder and shrimp paste to the annatto oil and cook briefly.
Add the chili oil mixture to the soup pot.
Season with fish sauce, sugar, and salt.
Remove beef shank from the pot and slice thinly.
Cook bún noodles according to package directions.
To serve, place noodles in a bowl, top with sliced beef shank, bean sprouts, shredded cabbage, mint, and cilantro. Ladle hot broth over the top. Serve with a lime wedge.

name: Chè Bà Ba (Mixed Sweet Soup)
description: A classic Vietnamese sweet soup with tapioca pearls, taro, sweet potatoes, and coconut milk.

instructions.step: Soak the mung beans in water for at least 2 hours.
Peel and dice the taro and sweet potatoes into bite-sized pieces.
Boil the tapioca pearls according to package instructions until translucent. Rinse with cold water and set aside.
Steam the soaked mung beans until soft. Set aside.
In a large pot, combine water, sugar, pandan leaves, and a pinch of salt. Bring to a boil, stirring until the sugar dissolves.
Add the taro and sweet potatoes to the pot and cook until tender, about 15-20 minutes.
Pour in the coconut milk and bring to a simmer. Do not boil.
Add the cooked tapioca pearls and steamed mung beans to the pot. Stir gently.
Simmer for another 5 minutes to allow the flavors to meld.
Remove the pandan leaves before serving.
Serve warm or chilled.

name: Bánh Mì Xíu Mại (Vietnamese Meatball Sandwich)
description: A delicious Vietnamese sandwich filled with flavorful pork meatballs simmered in a rich tomato sauce.

instructions.step: In a large bowl, combine ground pork, shallots, garlic, bread crumbs, egg, fish sauce, sugar, and black pepper. Mix well with your hands until evenly combined.
Form the mixture into small meatballs, about 1-inch in diameter.
Heat vegetable oil in a large pot or Dutch oven over medium heat. Brown the meatballs on all sides. Remove meatballs from pot and set aside.
Pour tomato sauce and water into the pot. Bring to a simmer. Add the meatballs back to the pot. Cover and simmer for 30 minutes, or until the meatballs are cooked through and the sauce has thickened.
While the meatballs are simmering, prepare the baguettes by slicing them lengthwise. Optionally, toast the baguettes lightly.
To assemble the bánh mì, spread a thin layer of Maggi seasoning sauce on the bottom half of each baguette. Add a generous portion of meatballs and sauce.
Top with pickled daikon and carrots, cilantro, cucumber slices, and jalapeno slices.
Serve immediately.

name: Cá Kho Tộ Nước Dừa (Fish Braised in Coconut Juice)
description: A classic Vietnamese dish of fish braised in a rich and savory coconut caramel sauce.

ingredients.name: Catfish fillets (or other firm white fish)

instructions.step: Marinate the fish: In a bowl, combine the fish with 2 tablespoons fish sauce, 1 teaspoon sugar, 1 tablespoon soy sauce, half of the shallots and garlic, and black pepper. Let it marinate for at least 30 minutes.

Prepare the caramel sauce: In a heavy-bottomed pot or clay pot (tộ), heat vegetable oil over medium heat. Add the remaining shallots and garlic and sauté until fragrant and golden brown. Add the remaining sugar and cook until it melts and turns into a dark amber caramel. Be careful not to burn it.

Braise the fish: Add the marinated fish to the pot and stir gently to coat it with the caramel sauce. Add the coconut juice, remaining fish sauce, and remaining soy sauce (if using). Bring to a simmer.

Cook the fish: Reduce heat to low, cover the pot, and simmer for 45-60 minutes, or until the fish is cooked through and the sauce has thickened to a syrupy consistency. Baste the fish occasionally with the sauce.
Serve: Garnish with chopped green onions and sliced red chilies (if using). Serve hot with steamed rice.

name: Canh Chua Cá Lóc (Sour Snakehead Fish Soup)
description: A classic Vietnamese sour soup with snakehead fish, vegetables, and a tangy tamarind broth.

instructions.step: Prepare the tamarind water: Soak the tamarind pulp in warm water for 15 minutes, then strain to extract the tamarind juice.
Prepare the fish: Clean the snakehead fish fillet and cut into bite-sized pieces. Marinate with a pinch of salt and pepper.
Prepare the vegetables: Chop the pineapple and tomatoes into wedges. Cut the okra into smaller pieces. Wash the bean sprouts, rice paddy herb, and Thai basil.
Sauté the aromatics: Heat oil in a pot and sauté minced garlic and shallots until fragrant.
Add the tamarind water: Pour the tamarind water into the pot and bring to a boil.
Add the vegetables: Add the pineapple, tomatoes, and okra to the boiling broth. Simmer for 5 minutes.
Add the fish: Gently add the marinated snakehead fish to the soup. Cook until the fish is cooked through (about 3-5 minutes).
Season the soup: Season with fish sauce, sugar, and salt to taste. Adjust the sourness and sweetness as needed.
Add the herbs: Add the bean sprouts, rice paddy herb, and Thai basil to the soup just before serving.
Serve hot: Ladle the Canh Chua Cá Lóc into bowls and serve hot with rice.

name: Bún Mọc (Pork Meatball Noodle Soup)
description: A flavorful Vietnamese noodle soup with pork meatballs, mushrooms, and delicate broth.

instructions.step: Soak wood ear and shiitake mushrooms in hot water for 30 minutes. Drain and finely chop.
Combine ground pork, chopped mushrooms, fish sauce, pepper, and minced shallots in a bowl. Mix well and form into small meatballs.
In a large pot, simmer pork bones in water for 30 minutes to create a richer broth. Skim off any impurities.
Add chicken broth to the pot. Bring to a boil and then reduce to a simmer.
Gently add the pork meatballs to the simmering broth. Cook until the meatballs are cooked through, about 15-20 minutes.
Cook rice noodles according to package directions. Drain and rinse.
Divide the noodles among bowls. Ladle the hot broth and meatballs over the noodles.
Garnish with bean sprouts, chopped cilantro, and chopped green onion.
Serve with lime wedges for squeezing.

name: Chè Đậu Đen (Black Bean Sweet Soup)
description: A classic Vietnamese sweet soup made with black beans, coconut milk, and tapioca pearls.

instructions.step: Rinse the black beans thoroughly and soak them in water for at least 4 hours, or preferably overnight.
Drain the soaked black beans and place them in a pot with 1500ml of fresh water.
Bring the water to a boil, then reduce the heat to low, cover the pot, and simmer for 60-90 minutes, or until the beans are tender.
Add the sugar and a pinch of salt to the pot and stir until dissolved. Simmer for another 10 minutes to allow the flavors to meld.
While the black beans are simmering, cook the tapioca pearls according to the package instructions. Drain and rinse them with cold water.
In a separate saucepan, heat the coconut milk over low heat. Be careful not to boil it.
To serve, ladle the black bean soup into bowls. Add a spoonful of cooked tapioca pearls and drizzle with warm coconut milk.  Add a dash of vanilla extract before serving.
Serve warm or chilled.

name: Bánh Rế (Sweet Potato Fritters)
description: Crispy and sweet Vietnamese sweet potato fritters, perfect as a snack or dessert.

instructions.step: Peel and grate the sweet potatoes finely.
In a large bowl, combine the grated sweet potatoes, rice flour, tapioca starch, sugar, coconut milk, salt, and vanilla extract.
Mix well until a smooth batter forms.
Heat vegetable oil in a deep frying pan or wok over medium heat. The oil should be deep enough to submerge the fritters.
Drop spoonfuls of batter into the hot oil, being careful not to overcrowd the pan.
Fry the fritters until golden brown and crispy, about 2-3 minutes per side.
Remove the fritters from the oil and drain on paper towels.
Serve warm and enjoy!

name: Cá Trê Nướng (Grilled Catfish)
description: A classic Vietnamese dish featuring grilled catfish marinated in flavorful spices.

instructions.step: Prepare the marinade: In a mortar and pestle (or food processor), combine lemongrass, garlic, and shallots. Grind into a paste.
In a bowl, mix the lemongrass paste with fish sauce, sugar, turmeric, and chili powder. Add vegetable oil and mix well.
Marinate the catfish: Rub the marinade evenly over the catfish fillets. Let them marinate for at least 30 minutes (or up to 2 hours) in the refrigerator.
Preheat the grill to medium heat.
Grill the catfish: Place the marinated catfish fillets on the preheated grill. Cook for about 5-7 minutes per side, or until the fish is cooked through and slightly charred.
Garnish and serve: Remove the catfish from the grill and garnish with chopped green onions.
Serve hot with steamed rice, fresh herbs, and dipping sauce (such as nuoc cham).

name: Gà Nướng Mọi (Grilled Chicken on Stick)
description: A simple and delicious Vietnamese grilled chicken recipe, marinated in flavorful spices and grilled on a stick.

instructions.step: Cut chicken thighs into bite-sized pieces.
In a large bowl, combine minced lemongrass, garlic, shallots, fish sauce, soy sauce, sugar, honey, black pepper, and vegetable oil.
Add the chicken pieces to the marinade and mix well. Ensure all pieces are coated.
Cover the bowl and marinate in the refrigerator for at least 30 minutes, or preferably 2 hours or overnight.
Thread the marinated chicken pieces onto skewers.
Preheat your grill to medium heat.
Grill the chicken skewers for about 20-25 minutes, turning occasionally, until cooked through and slightly charred.
Serve hot with rice, vermicelli noodles, or your favorite dipping sauce.

name: Canh Rau Cải (Mustard Greens Soup)
description: A simple and refreshing Vietnamese soup featuring mustard greens in a flavorful broth.

instructions.step: Wash and chop the mustard greens into bite-sized pieces.
Finely chop the shallots.
In a pot, heat a little oil and saute the shallots until fragrant.
Add the pork and cook until browned.
Pour in the chicken broth and bring to a boil.
Add the mustard greens and cook until tender (about 5-7 minutes).
Season with fish sauce, salt, and pepper.
Simmer for a few more minutes to allow the flavors to meld.
Serve hot.

name: Bún Xào Giòn (Crispy Fried Vermicelli)
description: A delightful Vietnamese dish with crispy fried vermicelli noodles topped with a flavorful stir-fry of vegetables and protein.

instructions.step: Soak the vermicelli noodles in warm water for about 10 minutes until softened. Drain well.

Heat vegetable oil in a large wok or skillet over medium-high heat. Divide the noodles into smaller bundles and fry in batches until golden brown and crispy. Remove and set aside on paper towels to drain excess oil.
In the same wok, heat 1 tablespoon of vegetable oil. Add minced garlic and chopped onion, and stir-fry until fragrant.
Add shrimp and sliced chicken breast. Cook until cooked through.
Add sliced carrots and bell peppers. Stir-fry for 2-3 minutes until slightly softened.
Add bean sprouts, soy sauce, oyster sauce, sugar, and sesame oil. Stir-fry until well combined.
Return the crispy fried vermicelli noodles to the wok. Gently toss to coat with the stir-fry sauce.
Garnish with chopped green onions and serve immediately.
